https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80236,2018,Supply Chain Governance and Competition  - A Game Theoretic Approach,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. GWJ Hendrikse'],,"Inhoud
Supply chain performance depends on the actions taken by all of the parties in the supply chain
column2: one weak link can negatively affect every other location in the chain. While everyone supports in principle the objective of optimizing the supply chain’s performance, each party’s primary objective is the optimization of its own performance. And unfortunately, self-serving behavior by each party of the supply chain can lead to less than optimal supply chain performance. For example, one party’s incentive to stock more inventory, or install more capacity, or to provide faster customer service, might not be the same as another firm’s incentive, thereby creating some conflicts between them. In those situations, the firms in the supply chain can benefit from changes in the governance of, and the competition in, the supply chain. This course develops the game theoretic approach to analyze these problems, and to formulate solutions for these problems.

column1: Governance of a supply chain is characterized by decision and income rights. Decision rights address the question ‘Who has control?’ Important themes are the allocation of authority (‘make-or-buy’ decision), formal versus real authority, relational contracts, access, decision control (ratification, monitoring), decision management (initiation, implementation), task design, conflict resolution, and enforcement mechanisms. Income rights specify the ‘Benefits and Costs’, thereby creating the incentive system faced by the supply chain parties. Important themes are payment schemes, compensation packages, cost allocation schemes, and the effects of horizontal as well as vertical competition. Successful governance of supply chains will contribute to accomplishing the three goals of providing (individual) incentives to develop the (joint) supply chain, coordinating the optimal combination of productive resources across parties, and to deal with the cognitive limitations of supply chain parties.

The game theoretic approach is introduced and applied to formulate the main insights. It addresses systematically the art of creating power in settings where a small number of players interact and the details of behaviour of each can make a big difference to the responses of the others, hence, to the outcome. Themes and patterns are identified that are common to situations in all fields of management, such as the capacity to think ahead, grasp how others think and behave, commitments, threats and promises, deception and trickery, strategies of signalling and the emergence of cooperation. Nowadays even seemingly diverse fields like supply chain management, corporate finance and organizational design are approached in a unified way by game theory. Game theory has therefore been described as one of the outstanding intellectual advances of the last decades (with Nobel prizes in 1994, 1996, 2001, 2005, 2007, 2012, 2014, and 2016). This course will develop the basic ideas of game theory and tailor them to the field of supply chain management. The lectures aim to present the core ideas as simple as possible.

A special feature of supply chains is that each of the multiple independent (individual) parties has a sizeable stake in the development and outcome of the (joint) chain. Game theory highlights the interactions between these multiple independent parties.
This week introduces the basics of a non-cooperative game, and applies them to supply chain concerns.
Reading: Gibbons, R., An Introduction to Applicable Game Theory, Journal of Economic Perspectives, 1997, 11(1), 127-149.
Week 2 Contract design in supply chains when actions are hidden

Supply chain activities are determined substantially by the available information. Information may be missing regarding the actual situation of the market (Uncertainty), the actual choices of some or supply chain parties (Hidden actions), or the characteristics of some or all supply chain parties (Hidden characteristics). Optimal contractual responses are highlighted for each of these three informational conditions in the weeks 2 and 3. This week highlights contract design issues when the characteristics and output of the decisions of the chain parties are observable, but not their actual decisions, i.e. information is imperfect.

The strength of incentives used in a supply chain and the productivity of its participants depend to a large degree on the characteristics of the performance measures available to the supply chain. Some supply chains use high-powered incentive contracts, while others have no explicit incentive contracts at all. This lecture examines the characteristics of performance measures to understand how firms use incentive contracting, and to predict the use of incentives in practice.
Reading: Krishan, H. and R.A. Winter, The Economic Foundations of Supply Chain Contracting, Technology, Information and Operations Management, 2011, 5(3-4), 147-169.

There are many ways to improve supply chain productivity, but none is more powerful than making the right hiring decision. Properly matching parties with tasks in the supply chain is the goal of the selection process. We highlight therefore contract design regarding selection issues when one or more characteristics of the chain parties are not observable, i.e. there is incomplete information.
Reading: Krishan, H. and R.A. Winter, The Economic Foundations of Supply Chain Contracting, Technology, Information and Operations Management, 2011, 5(3-4), 250-259.
Week 4 Business is war, and business is peace

Two schools of thought are distinguished regarding strategic supply chain situations. One school highlights ‘Business is war’, i.e. outsmarting the competition, capturing market share, making a killing, fighting brands, beating up suppliers, and locking up customers. Another school of thought emphasizes ‘Business is peace’, i.e. listen to customers, work with suppliers, create teams, and establish strategic partnerships - even with competitors. In other words, business is war and peace, i.e. business is competition when it comes to dividing up a pie and cooperation when it comes to creating a pie.

To find a way of bringing together the two seemingly opposing perspectives of competition and cooperation, we turn to repeated games. Players in a repeated game may overcome the inefficient prisoners dilemma outcome of a game which is played only once. These ideas are used to address stability of collusion, the transaction platform eBay, reputation, and empowerment.

However, there are often various stable outcomes, i.e. war as well as peace are equilibrium outcomes, which implies a need for coordination. Various ways to establish coordination are formulated in order to bring the system complementarities in the supply chain to value.
Reading: Krishan, H. and R.A. Winter, The Economic Foundations of Supply Chain Contracting, Technology, Information and Operations Management, 2011, 5(3-4), 285-289.

A challenge for many supply chain projects is how to create value and how to divide up the gains from cooperation. This week the focus is on cooperative game theory to address these questions. Power in supply chains, cost allocation, matching mechanisms, and the make-or-buy decision are addressed
Hendrikse, G.W.J., Cooperative Game Theory, in G.W.J. Hendrikse, Economics and Management of Organizations, Coordination, Motivation, and Strategy, McGraw-Hill, 2003, 284-288.
Krishan, H. and R.A. Winter, The Economic Foundations of Supply Chain Contracting, Technology, Information and Operations Management, 2011, 5(3-4), 260-284.

This week highlights the strategic considerations in supply chain investment decisions when there are a limited number of competitors. A strategy typology will be developed based on reaction functions, and delineates the optimal investment behaviour of the firm in various strategic settings in order to structure the market to its own interest. A variety of supply chain management issues are highlighted, such as capacity, spillovers, dynamic economies of scale, double markup and vertical integration, delegation, royalties/licenses, most-favored-customer-clauses, provision of information, supply chain standards, and so on.
The goal of this elective is to make you familiar with the topics at the frontier of the field Supply Chain Governance and Competition. We aim to achieve three goals:
<div>Provide insight in the governance of, and competition in supply chains
<div>Improve your supply chain thinking by game theory
Enable you to develop better supply chain management strategies.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80623,2018,Supply Chain Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. M Becker-Peth', 'dr. S Lemmens', 'prof.dr. JYF Wynstra', 'prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster']",,"Inhoud

Companies have over time specialized in a very limited number of business activities which they consider to be their core business. By doing so, they have been able to greatly increase their expertise, innovative capabilities and process efficiency. Companies have subsequently located their operations in regions that are most suitable in terms of natural resources, labour (either cheap or high grade), sales markets etc. As a consequence, a long chain of companies is involved in the manufacture of products. These companies have limited insight into each other’s operations, and are often dispersed around the world. Such a situation requires that the chain of companies is effectively managed otherwise processes would falter, customers would have to be disappointed, and costs would surge. Therefore, supply chain management is vital to companies that operate in such chains. Proper planning and managing of the supply chain can make the difference between a successful business and an outright failure.Progress in information technology has contributed to both the increasing need and opportunities for improved supply chain management. With IT, companies in a supply chain can be connected in real-time, which allows for efficient and effective sharing of information.The course program presents cases of real-world situations calling for appropriate state-of-the-art models and solution methods for the design, control and operation of supply chains.
The course Supply Chain Management builds on the knowledge obtained in the course Operations Management offered in Bachelor 1.
The course focuses on the design, planning, control, and improvement of supply chains operations.
In this course students are not only encouraged to acquire the necessary knowledge, but also to&nbsp
column2: develop a critical attitude to the position of firms in relation to various strategic and operational choices related to the supply chain.

column1: Make you conversant in the language of supply chain management
Allow you to see the role of supply chain management in the overall strategy and performance of the firm by providing a conceptual, strategic view of supply chain design and operations
Enhance your critical thinking, not only in the area supply chain management but also as a future general manager
Provide you with qualitative tools to identify, analyze, and manage basic supply chain management issues.
At the end of the course the student should be able to:
Identify and use the main concepts and terminology in the domain of supply chain management
Identify and describe the needed design features of the supply chain
Select and use the appropriate instruments and tools to construct a supply chain management solution for a given situation
Recognize and use the different inventory replenishment strategies to control inventory levels
Clarify and leverage the value of information sharing as assisted by information technology for the integrated supply chain
column2: describe and choose the correct purchasing and sourcing strategy dependent on the features of a supply chain

column1: Design the physical distribution in a supply chain and adopt the transportation accordingly
Identify the different (strategic) constructs for parties of the supply chain to collaborate, and to discuss and mitigate the accompanying risks
Analyze cases or real world situations and develop suitable supply chain management solutions.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80205,2018,Supply Chain Simulation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. I Bicer', 'dr.ir. M Mirzaei']",,"Inhoud

Modern supply chain management involves decision making in uncertain, dynamic, and complex environments. This course focuses on the use of simulation techniques to make better supply chain decisions under such conditions. For that purpose, the course combines relevant theoretical knowledge with immediate application of simulation techniques on computer-based tools.

In particular, we use Monte Carlo simulation, discrete event simulation, and Markov Chain Monte Carlo approaches. In all cases, real-life supply chains are represented in computer models. These models serve as a safe playground to study and evaluate supply chain decision making. We gain essential knowledge to improve supply chain performance.
The objective of this course is to provide you with the necessary skills to perform sound simulation studies, as well as to shape your understanding of supply chain decision making under uncertainty.
Particularly, the goals of this course are the following:
<div>• understand the concept of decision making under uncertainty
<div>• gain insight into how the quality of a solution is affected by unknown factors and by an unknown future
<div>• become familiar with the background of discrete event simulation, Monte Carlo method, and Markov Chain Monte Carlo method
• learn how to use simulation software tools, such as Arena, for modeling and solving decision making problems under uncertainty.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80208,2018,Supply chain forecasting,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. EA van der Laan', 'dr. J van Dalen', 'dr. R Kuik']",,"Inhoud

The forecasting of product demand, promotion success, risk events and capacity dynamics is an important every day decision making activity in companies throughout the supply chain. It directly affects inventory management, procurement and production decisions, logistics resources and financial planning. While forecasting influences the performance of individual companies, it also affects that of a supply chain as a whole.

<div>Various forecasting methods and techniques exist. Some may be more appropriate than others, depending on the specific planning task at hand and the quantity and quality of the available data. Regardless of the situation, the following five elements (Ord &amp
column2: Fildes, 2013) are paramount to the forecasting process and form the basis for this course:

column1: Purpose – For what specific goal do we need the forecast? Who is going to use it?
Horizon – How far ahead do we need to forecast?
Information – How much data is available? What is the quality of the data?
Value – How valuable is the forecast? How much would you invest in better forecasts?
Evaluation – What is the relative performance of appropriate forecasting methods?

Through the discussion of company cases and the analysis of real data this course elaborates on the consequences of a specific forecasting task on the above elements, the choice of method and supply chain organisation. Some of the themes covered are intermittent demand forecasting, promotions forecasting and collaborative forecasting.

We will introduce and examine those forecasting methods that are most used in practice, like moving average, simple exponential smoothing, linear exponential smoothing, Holt-Winter, judgment-based, Box-Jenkins arima models, Croston, etc. Students will learn how to apply these methods to real problems with real data and how the forecasting performance is affected by the choice of models. Moreover, they will learn about the interaction between forecasters and information systems, the influence of incentives of the planners on forecast performance and about the consequences of behavior of channel partners for the use of forecasts as input to the planning process. Course work consists of individual exercises and a group assignment in the form of a forecasting challenge.

<body>The course’s primary focus is the representation of surveillance and intelligence on screen (TV, film, documentary) and in discussion platforms. Surveillance and intelligence, related but distinct concepts, both go back a long way and it is worth exploring the historical dimensions of these concepts.&nbsp
column2: The theoretical literature is mainly concerned with the social, philosophical, and media perspectives on surveillance and intelligence. In the seminar we will see how developments in surveillance techniques give rise to questions about&nbsp

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81297,2018,Surveillance, visibility and reputation",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. D Trottier'],,"Inhoud

The continued growth of social media platforms, mobile devices and related cultural practices has contributed to a dramatic increase in the quantity of information that any individual or organisation can access. Citizens can use this information in an emerging cultural practice known as ‘digital vigilantism’ where they identify offensive behaviour and bring the offender to a kind of ‘online justice’ by making them visible through naming and shaming practices. These practices are manifest in digital and conventional media in the following ways:

1. Citizens can make use of social media platforms (such as Facebook, Twitter and Tumblr) as well as social news sites (such as Reddit or Geenstijl) to shame other individuals, as well as share personal details about the target (‘doxing’). In doing so they often make both the offending act as well as their own coordinated response meaningful to a broader public.

2. Citizens may also turn to online review platforms such as Amazon and Tripadvisor (or make use of review functions in Facebook or Google) to denounce and shame targets (for example, by leaving one-star reviews). They may also take advantage of other interactive functions in online platforms (such as comments, replies or retweets) as part of their campaign.

3. Finally, news media (including broadsheets, tabloids, and online venues such as Huffington Post and BuzzFeed) may also provide coverage of these campaigns. In doing so, they may challenge the narrative put forth by the citizens engaging in online shaming, all while augmenting the visibility of the incident.

These developments demand conceptual and empirical attention from emerging media scholars. Students will develop research questions addressing (aspects of) one of these focal points. They will design a small-scale research project, and collecting and analyzing&nbsp
column2: their own data to answer their questions.

column1: Note: The maximum number of students for this workshop is 12. The workshop is only accessible for MA MCS students and Research Master students SCMA. In case of less than 5 students the research
• State-of the art theory on the topic of surveillance, vigilantism and mediated shaming.
• Common research designs and methods to examine online denunciations.
• Design and execute a small scale empirical study on the topic of digital vigilantism.
• Report on their preliminary and conclusive research findings in oral and written form.

• Critically reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research, with an emphasis on challenges and oppertunities associated with research on and through digital media platforms.

This course provides insight in the sustainability challenges and the link to finance. The challenge is to move from the current short-termism (e.g. quarterly reporting) to long term thinking and to stress the role of finance professional as steward. From the investor side, the course discusses the academic evidence on social responsible investing. From the corporate side, the course analyses changes in business models and integrated reporting. As climate change is a long run phenomenon, the use of scenario analysis is explained.

column3: To understand the externalities in the sustainability challenges

To understand the financial stability risks from climate change
To get familiarity with ESG criteria
To get familiarity with scenario analysis

To appreciate the role of the horizon (ST vs LT) in sustainability
To link sustainability with the role of finance professional as steward (ethics course)

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80804,2018,Sustainability Grand Challenges,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. C Frey - Heger'],,"Inhoud

This module focuses on the sustainability grand challenges of our times. Sustainability grand challenges can refer to ecological as well as social problems, such as climate change, land degradation and natural disasters or global displacement, poverty and inequality. In most scenarios, it is a complex configuration of both. Grand challenges are global problems that require combined efforts and new innovative approaches to better understand and tackle them and the main learning goal of this course is collaboration in understanding and solving grand challenges.
Participants will collaborate to analyze sustainability grand challenges and how solutions may be formulated engaging multiple stakeholders and by thinking ‘out-of-the-box’.&nbsp
column2: Critically in this module, participants are required to work together creating a novel and commercially viable business solution to a real-world ‘sustainability case’. The case organization for 2019 is Commonland and its partner Wide Open Architecture in Australia (Previous cases include Heineken (2015), Boskalis (2016), Commonland/WIJ.Land (2017&amp

column1: Participants will thus work in teams and under significant time pressure to analyze the sustainability grand challenge and jointly formulate a credible ‘solution’. Groups will elaborate on their solution in a joint report as well as a presentation to a multi-stakeholder jury.
For this, groups will need to apply their learning of structuring and delivery of a message in time-restricted and context-sensitive ‘pitching’ format. Here, a ‘winning team’ will be selected.
Participants should attend and actively participate in the classes, are expected to engage in class discussions, ask questions of speakers, and demonstrate involvement with the in-class exercises.
Participation in the sessions is mandatory.
After completing this course, the participant is able to:
• Collaborate in analyzing a sustainability grand challenge using different theoretical frameworks and tools such as stakeholder management and innovation thinking
• Collaborate in developing practical solutions to the sustainability grand challenge, reflecting on the viability of the solution and summarizing those in a final report
• Jointly deliver a presentation pitch suitable for the boardroom

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80778,2018,Sustainability Leadership and Planetary Boundaries,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. SP Kennedy'],,"Inhoud

The reality check for business leadership is that nine billion people simply cannot live well in this world if companies do not start leading new partnerships to co-create a safe operating space for humanity. In this course we consider how business leaders are taking this challenge seriously.

The goal of this module is to broaden participants’ understanding of sustainability, allowing for a holistic recognition of the interconnectivity of issues and their impacts on the future of business. Participants will learn the basics concepts of corporate sustainability and the meaning of ‘true corporate sustainability’ from a holistic and embedded perspective. The module engages with how and why companies form sustainability strategies and considers how an embedded perspective can be achieved through tools such as the planetary boundaries framework.

The 2017/18 edition of the module will specifically engage with numerous corporate and external thought leaders in sustainability. Participants will be immersed in the contemporary advancements in sustainability leadership such as circular economy, integrated reporting and sustainability oriented innovation.
<div>Each year the course engages participants with a ‘Live Business Case’ (2013/14 Eosta
column3: 2015/16 Samsung). This requires participants to create sustainability strategies and present their ideas to managers of the company. &nbsp
column4: Details of this and other course assignments may be found on the blackboard learning environment.

Students are expected to engage in class discussions, ask questions of speakers, and demonstrate involvement with group exercises. Class attendance is mandatory for all classes, unless in the case of illness etc.
The participant is able to explain the core concepts of corporate sustainability and differentiate between perspectives and approaches.
The participant is able to understand ‘true corporate sustainability’ from a holistic and embedded perspective.
At the end of this module the participant is able to evaluate and develop strategies for sustainability.
At the end of this module the participant is able to explain the core concepts of contemporary issues in sustainable business such as circular economy and integrated reporting.
The participant is able to apply presentation skills to a boardroom setting.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80792,2018,Sustainability and Behavorial Ethics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. MJJ Wubben', 'dr. SP Kennedy', 'prof.dr. MH van Dijke']",,"Inhoud

With the global population growing to 9 billion people, the World Business Council for Sustainable Development forecasts that if organizations do not drastically revise their way of doing business, humanity will be consuming the ecological resources of 2.3 earths in 2050. To avert the disaster that would ensue, businesses need to develop in a sustainable fashion, meeting the needs of the present generation without compromising the needs of future generations. This implies an emphasis not only on economic development, but also on social and environmental development.

Nowadays, the sustainable mindset is frequently embraced by CEOs and employees alike, which greatly facilitates green innovations, initiatives to combat climate change, and corporate social responsibility in general. Yet it is also true that in contemporary business a dog-eat-dog mindset has survived. This mindset, which is anything but sustainable, has brought about various high-profile scandals such as the Enron, Worldcom, and Parmalat debacles, not to mention the global banking crisis. The economic, social, and environmental consequences of such drastic, moral transgressions may be so profound that they potentially nullify any sustainable development. Sustainability and ethics thus go hand in hand, and both present and future business leaders would do well to embody both.

This course offers a broad, psychological perspective on sustainable, moral behaviour in business. How can such behaviour be encouraged in employees, in CEOs, in organizations as a whole, and in their stakeholders? Conversely, how can unsustainable, immoral behaviour be averted? Such questions will be discussed in the context of, among others, pro-environmental behaviour, social dilemmas, greenwashing, ethical and sustainable leadership, and moral and sustainable development in individuals and organizations.

Central in this course is an evidence-based approach to business. The lectures are based on rigorous, empirical research, and they focus predominantly on linking fundamental, behavioural theories to sustainable, practical applications.

Linking theory, research and practice is also a main focus of the course assignments. As a first assignment, you and your research team will therefore either (a) carry out a quantitative research project on a topic of your choice relevant to sustainability, behavioural ethics or both, or (b) barring unexpected developments, conduct research on the sustainability of brands for the organization Rank a Brand, and provide advice to this organization. This will allow you to further interpret and understand the large body of available research on sustainability and behavioural ethics, as well as to subject your own ideas to empirical scrutiny, and to communicate your findings concisely, accurately, clearly and straightforwardly in a paper of 2500 words maximum. You and your team will also present your research to your fellow students, allowing you to further practice communicating your evidence-based ideas to an audience with some business and research experience.

The second assignment consists of an individual 1000-word essay where you will reflect on material from at least two different lectures. This gives you the opportunity to creatively process the course material. Perhaps you see previously unimagined potential in some of the theories discussed in the lectures, allowing you to propose brand new applications for sustainable development in business. Perhaps you see ways to improve existing theories and make them more relevant to practice. Or perhaps you are skeptical of certain theories, the link between theory and practice, or the value of the empirical research discussed in the lectures.
This course consists of six lectures, two consultation sessions, and one presentation session. Active participation during the lectures may count toward one’s final grade.
To understand the ways in which sustainability and morality are intertwined.
To understand what drives sustainable, moral behaviour in employees, in CEOs, and in organizations as a whole.
To become more self-aware of factors detracting from one’s moral and sustainable development.
To translate empirical research and theory on sustainability and business ethics into real-world interventions.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80238,2018,Sustainable Finance,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. D Schoenmaker'],,"Inhoud

This course provides insight in the sustainability challenges and the link to finance. The main task of the financial system is to allocate funding to its most productive use. Traditional finance focuses on financial return and regards the financial sector as separate from the society of which it is part and the environment in which it is embedded. By contrast, sustainable finance considers financial, social, and environmental returns in combination and shows how finance can accelerate the transition to a low-carbon, inclusive economy.

The course reviews evidence that environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors matter and explains in detail how to incorporate these in company business models and strategies, equity investing, bond investing, and bank lending. The course examines the financial instruments and techniques that can be applied in the context of evolving climate policies (and other sustainability policies). The tools will be applied in a group assignment on the valuation of a company based on ESG factors.</body>

<body>Students will learn to critically review the externalities embedded in sustainability challenges, to link climate change science with the evolution of financial markets, and to identify the sustainability risks and opportunities for financial professionals. In terms of applications, students will gain knowledge of the main metrics and financial instruments related to sustainability, and of the techniques to measure and manage the exposure of investment and lending portfolios.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80216,2018,Sustainable Strategies,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. FH Wijen', 'SM Musa, MSc', 'YT Wiessner, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Corporate sustainability, inclusive business, corporate (social) responsibility, and shared value creation have been widely embraced by a wide variety of firms. These buzz words basically refer to a firm’s pursuit of social and ecological objectives in addition to the classic economic goals. But what does a strategy to achieve corporate sustainability really look like?

Building on Hambrick and Fredrickson’s (Academy of Management Executive, 2005) well-known article “Are you sure you have a strategy?,” five components of a sustainable strategy will be identified: a sustainability logic (why to go for sustainable business?), sustainability differentiators (how to make a sustainability-related difference?), sustainability vehicles (how to engage a variety of stakeholders?), arenas of sustainable business (in what sustainability markets?), and staging of a sustainable strategy (how to unfold a sustainable strategy over time?).

You will first discover state-of-the-art literature at the interface of corporate strategy and corporate sustainability. Each of the five academic sessions will cover one core strategy component. You will study several relevant articles and make an individual assignment prior to the session. During the classes we will discuss strengths and limitations of the readings, relate each component to other strategy elements, and apply the topic to actual business practices.

Next to the classroom setting, you will conduct fieldwork in a group of students. You will observe a concrete firm that has recently implemented a sustainable strategy. In particular, you will identify a concrete (successful or failed) project—the environmental certification of a particular product, the internationalization of a ‘sustainable product’, development of inclusive business, etc.—and analyze this project using conceptual insights from the academic literature. Drawing on interviews and secondary data, you will comprehensively grasp the essence and details of the project, critically analyze the strengths and limitations of the adopted strategy, and offer constructive suggestions to the focal company to improve their practices. Every group will present the analysis and suggestions during the sixth and final session of the course.
Five academic lectures with individual assignments, field research by groups of students, and group presentations and reports
• To gain an in-depth theoretical understanding of the components and interrelations of economically, environmentally, and socially sustainable strategies
• To critically evaluate and compare different theories on sustainable strategies
• To chart the ‘real-life’ practices of sustainable business opportunities and threats
• To apply theoretical insights to the actual setting of a firm pursuing a sustainable strategy
• To develop the skills to analyze all factors and actors relevant to an actual sustainable business project

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80180,2018,Sustainable business models,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['prof.dr. RJM van Tulder', 'R Reshef, MA']",,"Inhoud

<div>Corporate leaders are nowadays searching for new and more innovative value propositions that can be linked to more future looking and crisis resilient business models. In the literature this tendency is also referred to as ‘shared value creation’,&nbsp
column3: or efforts of ‘sustainable leadership’. This course addresses these dimensions from a theoretical as well as practical point of few. One way of considering the question whether business models are actually sustainable&nbsp
column4: is the extent to which they address so called ‘wicked problems’ in society. Wicked problems are those problems that are not only difficult to solve, but even difficult to define. New business models in many sectors are developing that are trying to link up the value proposition of the company to the value gaps of society. Many large firms are doing this, next to the obvious smaller players (social enterprises). We see these new business models appear in such sectors as: care, health, international food, water provision, electricity and the like. How to understand and value these developments? This course also links up with a big NWO-funded programme in the Netherlands in which a number of universities and stakeholders collaborate to bring this theme further. The course thus will also bring you into touch with practitioners and researchers from many different areas. We consider this course also an excellent way of preparing your thesis as follow up on most of the themes of the first semester, but now applied to specific issues of sustainability for which companies have to come up with innovative business models.

column1: <div>Understanding how company’s ‘value proposition’ are created and implemented in the Netherlands and around the world
Get the know many version of the CANVAS model: PPP Canvas, etc. which can document and measure more sustainable business models (for instance taking negative and positive externalities into account)
Defining your own leadership potential and checking how leadership is needed for business model innovation
<div>Looking at new business models and the way they can create value and/or solve ‘ wicked’ &nbsp
<div>Understanding what the conditions of ‘ social enterprise’ &nbsp
column3: how can companies get out of the ‘valley of death’

column1: <div>Studying partnerships as part of sustainable business model innovation around the world
column2: from the perspective of companies, NGOs and governments

column1: Understanding what the business case for ‘shared value creation’?

column2: this elective will directly support your master thesis ambitions by linking theory to practice (and hopefully also practical applications) and providing with an opportunity to spend time on your master thesis during the elective.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90986,2018,System Based Auditing,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['J Thoms - van der Heul'],,"Inhoud

Companies in international trade must be compliant with rules and regulations. In the case of the EU, for instance the Union Customs Code. These rules are concerned with customs duties and taxation but also with trade agreements or safety and security. As we have seen in Essentials of Auditing, customs administrations are adjusting their regulatory supervision models and increasingly rely on the compliance efforts of the companies themselves. The company must produce evidence of compliance. How should data from the supply chain be represented, collected, monitored and evaluated, so that it can be used as evidence of compliance? And how do current IT-systems support a transparent and complete provision of data? How are such data sets analysed?

Just like for taxes, customs supervision has traditionally been influenced by audit and accounting. However, the abundance of data that is now becoming available in the supply chain, the challenges faced by businesses and customs organizations (safety and security
column2: supply chain visibility) and the availability of new approaches to regulatory supervision (self-regulation, risk-based supervision) lead to changes. Customs administrations increasingly deploy a system-based approach to regulatory supervision. By contrast to the transaction-based approach, this approach takes the entire system of controls into account, including the way in which companies collaborate in a supply-chain, their business processes and logistics operations, the information systems that implement and support the business processes and collect data, and crucially, the physical security measures that protect and monitor the stream of goods.

column1: In this advanced course we will look in particular at computational audit techniques that can be used both for analyzing and improving logistics processes (company), and for assessing compliance (regulator). These techniques are essentially data-driven. We will discuss data analytics in general, and its relative advantages and disadvantages. We will discuss continuous control monitoring, which makes it possible to evaluate controls at or near real time. We will discuss statistical audit, in particular monetary unit sampling, and how it is currently used in customs supervision. We will discuss process mining, a technique that makes it possible to visualize and identify bottlenecks in a process. Finally, we discuss model-based auditing, and argue that in addition to data analytics, we also need models of the norms to test against.

We will relate these techniques to the ‘data-driven vision’ on customs supervision, outlined in the beginning of the programme, and discuss applications of these techniques in the customs domain. For instance, students will apply process mining to assess compliance on the basis of a data set from a container terminals operation. Based on these examples, we will discuss the relative advantages and disadvantages of these computational audit techniques, and the circumstances under which they can be successfully applied.
<body>After this module, the student should be able to
• assess the adequacy of a system of controls for a specific regulatory objective
• describe the main characteristics of the following computational auditing techniques: data analytics
column5: model-based auditing, and discuss the advantages and disadvantages of these techniques in compliance settings,

column1: • apply a process mining software tool (Disco) in order to analyse a business process and
• discuss the impact of these techniques on regulatory customs supervision.

Music moves us physically and emotionally. Even when we don't move, brain areas related to movement are active when we hear music. Yet traditionally, music has by and large been studied from written scores, which can tell us many things. Scores do not, however, tell us how that music actually sounds or makes us feel. Moreover, it lacks the second most important aspect of music: movement. In recent years, developing technologies and blurring borders between scientific fields have paved the way for studying music from the perspective of human movement. Embodied Music Cognition is an exciting young field in musicology, which has as its core premise that movement in all its facets provides a unique window into musical and human behaviour. This course introduces students to many facets of the field, including the origins and purpose(s) of music, neuroscience, digital audio and emotions, and offers 4 weeks of intensive hands-on experience with students running, analysing and writing up their own music research project.

After completing the course students will be able to discuss the link between music (perception) and human movement, especially in terms of evolutionary auditory specialization, in terms of interpersonal coordination and in terms of the effects of musical training on the brain. Students will be able to argue that without movement, there is no music, neither played nor perceived. Students will have had an introduction to several behavioral measurement techniques, digital audio analysis, experiment design, as well as scientific reporting. Finally, students will be able to bridge gaps between research fields in the sense of applying existing research methods and questions to a field that these methods were not developed for.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80152,2018,Taxation,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. S Kohlhase'],,"Inhoud

Taxes affect many business decisions, such as: where to invest, what organizational form to choose, how to finance a business, when and where to recognize revenues and expenses. This is an introductory course providing you with an overview of what taxes exist, to which natural or legal persons they apply, how taxation affects business decisions, and what the fundamentals of domestic and international taxation are.

The course combines financial accounting, tax accounting, and investment principles to answer the question: How do I take tax-optimal business decisions? This knowledge is complemented by information about political developments in the area of taxation. The content from the lecture is applied and deepened during workshops. Guest lectures provide additional insights from practice.

The fundamentals in domestic and international taxation form basic knowledge of auditors, tax advisors, and practitioners in the accounting or tax departments of multinationals. Thus, the course is of interest to those contemplating careers in accounting, consulting, and corporate finance.
At the end of this course students are able to:
<div>Identify different types of taxes levied by governments
<div>Identify which taxes are relevant for businesses
<div>Solve tasks where taxes are included in financial planning
<div>Compare characteristics of corporate taxation vs. taxation of partnerships
<div>Analyze the impact of taxation on organizational form choices
<div>Define when profit taxation for businesses and when shareholder level taxes apply
<div>Give examples on the treatment of tax-loss carryforwards
<div>Are able to apply double tax agreements
<div>Are able to apply multilateral agreements in the area of international taxation
Discuss multiple viewpoints in teams, present and defend joint findings in a report and in front of the class.

This course is designed to assist students who aim to do case studies with making choices in setting up their own research project. For this reason, the theoretical part of the course, which revolves around a set of methodological principles involved in doing case-based research, is placed in function of the application of a set of more hands-on tools and instruments.
The course is built on the awareness that there is no one single case-study method, but that case studies contain a variety of research techniques. The course places emphasis on the principles of

case-study selection and the variety of case-study designs. As such, the course stresses the need for a firm grounding of case studies in social-science theory, since case studies are potentially strong tools for arriving at descriptive conclusions on causal effects.

Throughout the course, students will be requested to maintain a diary that describes the steps of their learning process. Through writing diary entries, students are forced to reflect on what they learn and how their learning impacts on their thoughts on doing a case study. The course is assessed by the diary plus a set of assignments related to examples of case studies.</body>
Upon completion of the course, students
have obtained knowledge on the main reasons for doing case-study research
have increased their ability to select the proper cases for their research project
have enhanced their ability to apply certain relevant techniques within a case-study research design.

This course is meant for participants with a broad interest in policy-oriented research. Although the course aims to be interesting and challenging for participants with serious research ambitions, it is also meant for participants who, in their work with either governmental agencies or non-governmental organizations, will not undertake elaborate research projects themselves, but who are expected to be able to gather and analyse information, and commission and assess research work undertaken by others.

The course starts with some mathematical techniques to introduce participants how handle numbers from three different perspectives: (1) to deal with order of magnitude (absolute or relative), (2) to deal with structure of composition, and (3) to deal with change. The second part of the course deals with the collection of quantitative secondary data (from national sources such as census and international sources such as the World Bank), its analysis and presentation, and aims to enhance intellectual insights in the research process, as well as improve concrete research skills. A prerequisite to the course is some basic knowledge of spreadsheet packages like Excel, for example a pass grade of at least 70% in the ECDL test and a willingness to engage with quantitative data.</body>
The broad objectives of the course are to:

column5: improve skills in working with numbers
improve skills to use quantitative data for research and policy analysis
improve skills to order, present, analyse and interpret quantitative data
improve the ability to construct valid evidence-based arguments as well as to assess the validity of arguments made by others
enhance quantitative skills required for writing the research paper.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80161,2018,Technology Enabled Businesses, Markets and Policy",Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. JH Oh'],,"Inhoud
<div>Advances in IT have transformed the market microstructure of many industries. Financial services, commercial services, entertainment, media and news industry, the hi-tech &amp
column2: telecommunications sectors, manufacturing, retailing, energy and transportation will all experience significant structural change. We investigate how these developments influence the business practices, profitability of corporations and digital policy. In each case of industry, we will analyze the linkages between market structure, resulting digital policy options that are open to firms and government and how information technology can be deployed in support of these strategies and policy regimes.

column1: <div>The course will emphasize the use of economic frameworks to raise and answer questions and to analyze options open to businesses. Discussions and analyses will be about formulating frameworks that bring out the limitations of the traditional responses of businesses when faced with changes and uncertainties about the market. &nbsp
column2: Students will acquire hands-on-experience with analytical methods in analyzing business and industry structure, optimal policy and strategy.

column1: We investigate how specific technologies change market structure and policy regimes in various industries including financial sector, digital product market, and global economy. The objective of the course is to provide students with the ability to construct a simple economic framework to understand the market structure and its linkage to policy. In this course students will be exposed to frameworks that will help them analyze the impact of technology on specific industry verticals, develop scenarios and formulate the firms’ optimal response under policy regimes. They will understand how information technology affects optimal policy and strategic options available, and will understand how customers, firms and industries are likely to be affected. At the end of the course students should have a thorough understanding of the following topics:
How to analyze the challenges and limitations of business strategies when they face changes in technology and uncertainties about its impact on market structure.
Role of education in digital economy and MOOC
Economic foundation of freemium vs. premium business models.
Rise of prosumers, sharing economy, and social enterprises.
Overview of the digital worker productivity and race against machine.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80612,2018,Technology Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. CW Hagen', 'dr. PL van den Berg', 'SGM Langeveld, MSc']",,"Inhoud

For centuries, technology has been one of the most important pillars of the economy. Both in production-oriented sectors and in service companies, technology plays an important role. Without technological progress, companies will lose their competitive advantage. Managers have to face the question of how to make the most of technology. What technology is available and which technological innovations are developing? What might be the consequences of a technology for a company, a particular sector or society? What is the role of technology in the strategy of a company regarding its product/services, the production process and the core competencies? In short, how can managers recognize relevant technologies and properly implement them in a company?

In the course Technology Management students will develop a technology strategy for one crucial high-tech technology embedded in a core product of a case company by combining technological and business criteria. The students will explore the technological advantages and disadvantages of the current technology embedded in the product, as well as two alternative technologies that could be selected for the product. In order to make that selection the students will also analyse the company and its business environment. The students will also explore the consequences of this selection for the company&rsquo
column2: s business functions such as R&amp
column3: D, HRM, operations, supply chain, marketing, etc.&nbsp

column1: This course describes how technology can be used in companies. It does not focus on the question of how to meet a short-term demand in the market by means of technology (market pull), but the focus will be on how an upcoming technology can be used in the longer run for redesigning products/services, production processes or core competencies of a company (technology push). Before the start of the course each student team selects a case company from a list of high tech companies. Each company uses a specific technology in its high tech product. By self-study, mandatory meetings and voluntary meetings, student teams will write a strategic plan for their company that could apply an alternative technology in one of its core products. In order to reach that goal the team has to analyse the company&rsquo
column2: s current technology and characteristics (Assignment 0), compare the current technology with the emerging ones (Assignment 1), study the effects of emerging technologies on the company and its environment (Assignment 2), and combine this information into a proposal for a technology strategy (Assignment 3), which has to be summarized and presented during an executive presentation (Presentation). The student teams consist of about 4 RSM students and about 2 students from Delft University of Technology. The teams will be guided by two coaches
column4: Note that there is no exam for this course, but that 4 specific meetings are mandatory without exception (including meetings where the student&rsquo

column1: <div>This course is a cooperative effort between RSM and Delft University of Technology (TUD). The objective of this course is to learn to cooperate with students with an engineering background. Together you will be assigned to a case company. You will get&nbsp
column2: an insight into specific high-tech technologies that can offer great value to the case company. In this course you learn to analyse a technology and discover how a company can exploit this technology by combining engineering knowledge with management knowledge.

column1: After successful completion of this course you should be able to:
<li>Cooperate with students with an engineering background
<li>Use a technology driven method as an alternative way to develop competitive products/services and production processes
<li>Judge the impact of a technology on an organisation and its environment
• Write a strategic recommendation for the case company regarding their future use of technology.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81809,2018,Technology and Social Change,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. M Wehrle'],,Inhoud

<body>Technology evidently enables us to control, organize and optimize the activities and functions of our everyday lives. However, a classical critique in the Philosophy of Technology is that technology also creates a distance between us (as individuals), and the surrounding world. In this regard, the great developments in technology arguably lead to the illusion that everything around us is controllable, rendering us ‘safe’ at a distance. Other approaches focus instead on the mediating and connecting function of technology, which opens up new ways of experiencing and communicating. Some of the questions that motivate this course are: does technology really help us to disclose the world and connect with others, or rather does it alienate us from nature, others and even ourselves?&nbsp
column2: How is society affected by technology? Are we shaping technology or does technology shape us and our social lives?&nbsp

column1: To tackle these problems, we first have to ask what do we mean when we talk about ‘technology’. This implies a reflection on the development of technology and its changing meaning, function and role within society
column2: from machines of mass production to virtual communication and the digital realm. This course offers an introduction into the different perspectives on how to understand the relationship between technology and the social lifeworld of human beings
column3: to question, how do technological developments and social changes interact?

column1: We will track the parallel changes of technologies and societies by analyzing and comparing texts and concepts within the Philosophy of Technology and recent STS, like ‘alienation’, ‘mediation’, ‘network’ as well as ‘technological determinism’, ‘domestication’ and ‘social shaping’. These concepts and approaches will be illustrated by focusing on recent developments in the field of Information and Communications Technology (ICT) and the internet more broadly.&nbsp
column2: Finally, we will discuss possible approaches to an ethics of technology.</body>

column1: <div>- To acquire basic knowledge of the concepts and debates (and their development) of the Philosophy of Technology, as well as, key perspectives in recent Science &amp
- To describe and analyze technological developments with regard to their relation to social changes.
- To compare and contrast the different kinds of scientific reasoning relevant to the Philosophy of Technology and technological sciences.
- To reflect critically on the assumptions, strengths and limitations of the different perspectives and concepts of technology.
- To apply this knowledge and analyze how technology and society mutually shape each other, with specific focus on the role of digital technologies.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82448,2018,Technology, Policy and Society",Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['dr. VMF Homburg', 'dr.ir. EA Rijshouwer']",,"Inhoud

<body>Today’s society is characterized by many as an information society. The industrial society, which was typical for the 19<sup>th</sup> and the first half of the 20<sup>th</sup> century, has transformed because of economic and cultural changes into a society in which information and information dissemination are central. The course technology democracy and society focusses on the role of modern ICT&nbsp
column2: within today’s society and in today’s democracy. The course will elaborate on which societal transformations are set in motion by the use of modern ICT and which consequences these societal transformations can have for the way in which ICT is used and perceived within society. Additionally topics such as chain information between organizations, interplay between technology and democracy and ethical issues will be discussed. In this course the main topics within the public sector related to technology will be addressed, among others, how big and open data influences the policy process, how computerized predictions can impact the way actors make decisions within matters in the public domain such as water management, climate change or safety and security and how this changes the dynamics of power within policy making, also we will address how the role of policy makers and those involved in the public sector changes into an information broker. Subsequently these changes have an effect on society and this effect will also be elaborated on.

column1: • Name which patterns and changes form the basis of today’s information society
• Explain how dynamics within the policy process within the public sector change as a result of technology and the emergence of an information society and how this reflects on society
• Explain how public organizations and those employed there change as a result of technological change
• Explain in which shape technology is applied in organizations and cooperation between organizations
• Report on the way in which organizations use ICT
• Name ethical dilemmas regarding the use of technology
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81304,2018,Television Audiences,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. JC van Sterkenburg'],,"Inhoud

<body>Central in this course are the television audience and audience reception research. We will explore how television audiences interpret and receive popular television genres and ‘texts’. We will pay attention, amongst other things, to the role played by social dimensions like race, ethnicity, gender, (dis)ability, social class, religion, in audience receptions. Television can be considered a powerful source for giving meaning to these social dimensions but different viewers can negotiate and interpret these meanings in different ways.&nbsp
column2: Various forms of qualitative data-collection and – analysis will be discussed in order to prepare students to do independent research into television audiences.

column1: N.B. A maximum of 12 students can participate in this course. The course is only accessible for the M&
column2: C students, MCS students and research master SCMA students

column1: Students get an intense training in designing, executing, and reporting on qualitative empirical research in the field of television audiences. The course guides students through the entire research process and students learn how the different components of qualitative television research relate to each other. Students also learn some practical skills for doing qualitative research into TV audiences and they will reflect critically on methodological and theoretical articles in the field. The course broadens students’ knowledge on audience reception research, with a specific focus on television.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/83586,2018,Television in the Digital Age,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. ML Wayne'],,"Inhoud

Since becoming popular in the United States and Great Britain during the late 1940s and early 1950s, television has been one of the most important cultural forms in the global mediascape. Mindful of this past, this course will explore contemporary issues in television studies as the medium continues to be remade by digital technologies. How does time-shifting technology fundamentally alter our conceptions of TV? What does mobile viewing mean for the television industry? What does the emergence of 'quality TV' imply about TV's rich past as a shared cultural product? To explore these issues, this course will use a variety of interdisciplinary paradigms to understand television in a digital context. Course readings and seminars address three main topics: television industries, television texts, and television audiences.
Students will have gained knowledge and understanding of:
<li>The impact of digitization on the production, distribution, and consumption of television
<li>Theoretical approaches and key concepts related to digital television
• Perspectives on digital television at the level of industry, audience, and text,

column10: &nbsp

column1: <li>Analyze and explain how digital television does and does not differ from traditional television
• Reflect critically on the mainstream and academic discourses surrounding digital television.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/78964,2018,Testvaardigheden I,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. AY Ganushchak'],,Inhoud

Het practicum dient als een eerste kennismaking met het observeren en testen van kinderen. Tijdens het practicum zullen een aantal psychometrische basisbegrippen aan de orde komen evenals hoe individuele verschillen te meten zijn.
Aan het einde van dit practicum zijn studenten in staat om:

afname, scoring en interpretatie uit te voeren van enkele intelligentietests en sociale competentietests voor kinderen met de ethische kwesties die daarbij in acht genomen moeten worden (eindtermen 10, 13 en 14)
een professioneel terugkoppelingsgesprek uit te voeren (eindtermen 16 en 17)
een professioneel, samenhangend en helder testrapport met de geëigende structuurindeling te schrijven (eindtermen 15 en 16)
te reflecteren op de eigen competenties, feedback te vragen en te ontvangen (eindtermen 18 en 19).

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/79959,2018,Testvaardigheden II,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['MJ van Swieten, MSc', 'RJ Zijderveld, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Het doel van het practicum ‘Testvaardigheden II’ is het toepassen van de theorie die in blok 1.5 ‘Changing Man’ wordt behandeld. Studenten maken kennis met het gebruik van ontwikkelingspsychologische tests in het kader van wetenschappelijk onderzoek. De tests die worden aangeboden, sluiten aan bij een van de problemen die in de onderwijsgroep worden behandeld.

In dit practicum gaan studenten oefenen met de afname van ontwikkelingspsychologische tests bij kinderen en het rapporteren van de resultaten van een dergelijke test in een onderzoeksverslag. Daarnaast zullen de studenten zich ook bekwamen in het zoeken van passende literatuur om een goed theoretisch beeld van de test en het bijhorende ontwikkelingspsychologische concept te kunnen schetsen.
<div>Aan het einde van dit practicum zijn studenten in staat om:
• een ontwikkelingspsychologische test af te nemen bij een kind aan de hand van gerichte instructie en begeleiding.
• observaties tijdens een testafname op een gestructureerde wijze bij te houden.
• gegevens die tijdens de testafname verzameld zijn te interpreteren.

• een wetenschappelijk onderzoeksverslag met de geëigende structuurindeling te schrijven over een ontwikkelingspsychologische mijlpaal (objectpermanentie, conservatie, executief functioneren, theory of mind, of morele ontwikkeling).
<li>een heldere en samenhangende presentatie te houden over een ontwikkelingspsychologische mijlpaal en bijbehorend onderzoek met behulp van audiovisuele hulpmiddelen
• eigen werk kritisch te beschouwen en op basis van feedback te verbeteren.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/79014,2018,Testvaardigheden IV,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['MJ van Swieten, MSc', 'RJ Zijderveld, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Dit practicum bouwt voort op practicum 1.4, 1.5, 1.6, 2.1 en 2.6, waarin studenten hebben geoefend met ontwikkelingspsychologische en neuropsychologische testafname en de schriftelijke en mondelinge rapportage van testresultaten. In dit practicum maken studenten kennis met testmaterialen die zijn ontwikkeld om cognitieve capaciteiten in kaart te brengen en schoolse vaardigheden te meten. Studenten zullen een ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek bij een typisch ontwikkelend kind afnemen. De testafname zal plaatsvinden in de thuissituatie van het kind waar aan de hand van gestandaardiseerde instrumenten de cognitieve capaciteiten en taalontwikkeling onderzocht zal worden. Daarnaast zal ook de opvoedingsomgeving in kaart worden gebracht, waardoor de scores op intelligentie en taalontwikkeling in de bredere opvoedingscontext van het kind kunnen worden geïnterpreteerd.

Een ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek bestaat veelal uit meerdere tests over verschillende ontwikkelingsdomeinen om op die manier voldoende informatie te verzamelen en goed zicht te krijgen op de aangemelde problematiek. Door in het ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek zowel eventuele leerproblemen, als gedragsproblemen en cognitieve vaardigheden in kaart te brengen, wordt een volledig beeld gevormd van de sterktes en zwaktes van het kind en kunnen verklaringen gevonden worden voor eventuele leerachterstanden op school. Ook de opvoedingsomgeving (denk aan: gezinsstructuur, ouderfactoren en leefomgeving) en de sociaal-emotionele ontwikkeling van het kind kunnen een rol spelen in de cognitieve en gedragsontwikkeling van het kind. Daarom wordt in dit practicum een variatie aan tests en vragenlijsten behandeld die kunnen worden gebruikt in het diagnostisch proces en in gezinspedagogisch onderzoek.

Veel van het materiaal dat wordt gebruikt in het practicum is gelieerd aan de praktijk. Zo worden bijvoorbeeld de Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children (WISC) en de Taaltoets alle Kinderen (TAK) behandeld die door orthopedagogen tijdens de diagnostiek van onder andere ontwikkelingsstoornissen en leerstoornissen worden gebruikt. De gemeten cognitieve capaciteiten worden doorgaans in het bredere kader van o.a. schoolprestaties geïnterpreteerd door bijvoorbeeld ook gebruik te maken van (andere) CITO toetsen. Hiertoe wordt een verplicht practicumcollege gegeven dat zal ingaan op het CITO leerlingvolgsysteem op school. Daarnaast wordt de ontwikkeling van het kind in de complexe werkelijkheid onderzocht door kennis te maken met een instrument die de opvoedingsomgeving van het kind in kaart brengt. Hiermee wordt de link van praktijk naar pedagogisch wetenschappelijk onderzoek gemaakt. De vaardigheden die de student opdoet in dit practicum kunnen worden toegepast in een praktijkstage of onderzoeksstage in de bachelorfase en masterfase.

Naast het oefenen met het afnemen van het testmateriaal, zal de student de verkregen gegevens verwerken in een testrapportage en oefenen met het terugkoppelen van testresultaten aan een fictieve ouder. De testafname en het oudergesprek worden geëvalueerd in een zelfreflectieverslag.</body>
Aan het einde van dit practicum zijn studenten in staat om:
<li>een uitgebreid ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek af te nemen bij een kind (eindtermen 5 en 10)
<li>de opvoedingsomgeving van het kind te observeren en te coderen met behulp van gestandaardiseerde, gevalideerde instrumenten (eindtermen 5 en 10)
<li>bevindingen uit het ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek op een praktijkgerichte manier te beschrijven
<li>bevindingen uit het ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek terug te koppelen aan een ouder
<li>peerfeedback te geven en ontvangen en op basis hiervan eigen werk kritisch te beschouwen en te verbeteren (eindtermen 18 en 19)
• en zonder instructie en met enige begeleiding (onderdeel schrijfonderwijs):
<li>een samenhangende en heldere tekst te schrijven (eindterm 15)
<li>een professionele schrijfstijl toe te passen (eindtermen 15 en 16)
• een testrapport met de geëigende structuurindeling te schrijven (eindtermen 15 en 16).
