https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80295,2018,The Art of Filmmaking,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['A Ozgen Havekotte -'],,"Inhoud

When studying art and culture, film is one cultural discipline that demands our attention. In all its diversity, film is an extremely popular art form. It constitutes a major industry and its stories, characters, and taglines have found their way into mainstream culture. In this course, we explore the art of filmmaking from various academic perspectives. We discuss the historical development of cinema as an entertainment industry as well as film as art. We learn to use and read film grammar, and analyse filmic content. We discuss major topics in film criticism and film theory. Finally, we consider the reception and effect of films within their social, cultural, and political contexts.
Attending the weekly lectures is strongly advised, but not mandatory. Please make sure you arrive on time.
The aims of the lecture sessions are multifold:
- To sketch the broad outlines of the weekly course subjects, thereby largely following the outlines of the provided literature
- To investigate selected key aspects of the course subjects deeper, mainly by means of case studies on specific films and excerpts from the contemporaneous writings
- To illustrate the course subjects and the case-studies by means of clips from movies and documentaries
- To learn analysing the moving image and its meaning-making mechanisms
- To learn reading film grammar through five concepts introduced every week in relation to the topic of the lecture
- To learn questioning and criticising the established narratives of cinema culture and history.
The lecture slides will be published on Canvas after the lecture.

Students gain insight into film history, film production techniques, world cinema industries, film grammar, methods of film analysis and major topics in film theory. They learn to consider this popular art form from different academic perspectives.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80362,2018,The Avant-Garde: Experimental Art, Photography and Film",Engels,Erasmus University College,,"['CJG Somzé, MA', 'dr. R van den Akker']",,"Inhoud

Avant-Garde is the French military term for front-guard and is generally used to describe the most adventurous manifestations of modern art. Art that forges ahead, breaks down barriers and challenges the status quo, but at the same time, art that is difficult, sometimes incomprehensible and elitist. Through a combination of the humanities and sociological perspectives, we will trace the roots of the Avant-Garde, examine the challenges that avant-garde artists faced and discuss whether avant-garde art is still possible today. All this will lead up to a symposium that we will organise at the end of the course, during which students will present and discuss short papers about the several themes that we discussed during our lectures and museum visit.

The aim of the course is to create insight into the relationships between the visual arts and society for approximately the last 150 years. Students will become familiar with the most influential visions on avant-garde art, the most influential critiques of avant-garde art, and the most ‘canonical’ examples of avant-garde art. Students will be able to think, write and talk about avant-garde art in its historical and social context
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/78850,2018,The Brain,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. L Gootjes'],,Inhoud

The brain: maybe the most important organ of our body. Without the brain we would not be aware of anything around us. The world would not exist for us. It’s not our eyes that make us see, it’s not our ears that make us hear. It is only in our brain were we become aware of what we see and what we hear. In this course you will learn about this exciting organ, the brain, with its neural circuits giving rise to psychological functions like cognition and emotion.

Everything that happens in the brain is the result of interactions between brain cells, the neurons. Neurons communicate with each other through chemical substances. In this block you will learn how this communication takes place and what happens when this communication goes wrong in clinical disorders like depression and schizophrenia. You will also learn how the brain develops, how neural circuits arise and how these are subject to modifications as a result of experience.

Brain research is constantly giving us new ideas about how the brain works and what happens when things seem to go wrong in the brain. There are still many things that we (or better ‘science’) do not exactly know about the brain. This makes it a very exciting topic to study. If everything would be known already, it would be less fun. Actually, some say that we might never be able to understand the brain completely. As L. Watson, a well-known scientist, said: &nbsp
column10: &nbsp

column1: ”If the brain were so simple we could understand it, we would be so simple we couldn't.”
Indeed, brain is a comprehensive subject.&nbsp
column2: You will learn a lot of new names and terms and this might be a little confusing in the beginning. When you feel like this, just think of the following quote from another scientist, W. Rogers:&nbsp

column1: “You know you've got to exercise your brain just like your muscles"".</body>
<body>At the end of this course, you will have a deeper understanding of

column9: the cellular basis of brain functioning and neural circuits (including the role and working of neurotransmitters and receptors, and the cascade that the binding of a neurotransmitter to a receptor sets off).
how neural circuits arise in the development of the brain.
how modifications of neural circuits take place as a result of experience and learning
the biological basis of brain dysfunctions (e.g. psychiatric disorders) and the working of psychotropic drugs
the process of recovery after brain damage, involving neuroplasticity

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81229,2018,The Business of Media,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud
<body>The media sector is an important economic industry that is increasingly expanding into other sectors such as healthcare or connected vehicles. During this course we focus&nbsp
column10: our main&nbsp

column1: During the classes we will discuss how media firms design value&nbsp
column2: propositions, engage with customers, produce content and services (value chains), manage their organizations and generate revenues. We will address the impact of new (digital) media technologies on the business models of media firms. Furthermore, we will also look at specific business related issues that media firms face in specific sectors, such as TV, gaming and digital video. We will also address how government policy impacts business models of media firms, for instance around copyrights, privacy and competition law.

column1: An important part of this course consists of guest lectures by people that work in media companies. These guest lecturers will familiarize students with real life experiences around the topics that will be discussed.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 60. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

column4: concepts and current developments in the field of media business and media management

column2: operations of contemporary media organizations from a management and business perspective

column1: • Read, critique, and apply relevant theoretical concepts to specific business related issues faced by media firms

column4: reflect upon the use of business models by media firms

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81119,2018,The Changing Social and Economic position of the Arts in Society: A combined economic, sociological and historic approac",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. J Roscam Abbing'],,"Inhoud
Firstly the course provides insight into the different ways economists and sociologists analyze phenomena in the arts and whether these approaches can or cannot supplement one another.
Secondly the course looks at broad developments in the arts from both a sociological and an economic perspective.

In the 19th century there has been a process of transition in the arts. Part of the arts became serious and less commercial when nonprofits were established. Over the last 50 years there has again been a far-reaching process of transition. The latter will be the main topic of the course.

We will examine the changes during this period in the social and economic position of the established as well as popular arts taking into account longer term developments. Together we will attempt to answer several questions. How did the established arts become so serious? Is this presently changing? Have artists lost their monopoly on creativity and authenticity? Is there less respect for art? Why is the value of authorship still high in the arts? Why was the rejection of commercial behavior and the pursuit of profit so strong? How to explain and interpret the present re-commercialization in the arts? And why are artists still not allowed to “compromise”, even though the taboo on marketing and cultural entrepreneurship has largely disappeared? Why are artists still prepared to work for very low incomes? Are artists exploited by nonprofits? And so forth.</body>

Students learn about the transitions in the arts that have taken place in the past 50 years and how (the absence of) transitions can be explained. They learn which historical developments are important for a proper understanding of the present state of the arts, and why these developments are not only social, cultural or economic. Among other things, they learn about the effects on art worlds and artists of the present re-commercialization in the arts and the fading of some boundaries between the established and popular arts, as well as about the reactions they cause among artists, art organizations and in society.

Those students who are familiar with the tools of the sociologist learn that these can fruitfully be combined with the tools economists use, and vice versa. Both groups learn about the possibilities but also the limitations of each other’s tools.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80380,2018,The Climate Crisis: Ecology, Economy & Politics in the Anthropocene",Engels,Erasmus University College,,[],,"Inhoud

There is consensus among scientists in fields that are contributing to the study of climate change that mankind has a negative impact on our climate and that we are rapidly running out of time to avert a catastrophically changed climate. Still we – mankind, as a whole - do not seem to be in a hurry to change the ways in which we have organized our everyday lives, our economies and our societies. Why? And what is to be done?

In this course we discuss the ways in which we shape the climate and the climate has shaped, and will continue to shape, us – from the very distant past to the not so distant future. By combining perspectives from ecology, philosophical anthropology, political economy and (geo)politics students get a thorough introduction in the problematic of climate change. Throughout the course we pay particular attention to the concept of the Anthropocene as well as its uses and abuses in popular discourse and academic disciplines as varied as climate sciences, geology, social sciences or the humanities.</body>
<li>Have a basic understanding of the causes and consequences of Climate Change
<li>Have a basic understanding of the debate about the (use and abuse of the term) Anthropocene
<li>Have a basic understanding of economic solutions to climate change
<li>Have a basic understanding of the politics of climate change
<li>Have a basic understanding of the pros and cons of technological fixes
<li>Have a basic understanding of the SF mode in both its literary and theoretical sense
• Have an advanced understanding of the work of key thinkers on Climate Change such as Latour and Haraway, Moore and Giddens and Morton and Jonas.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80292,2018,The Cultural Economic Perspective,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. T Navarrete Hernandez'],,"Inhoud

<body>The main objective of this course is to familiarize students with key concepts and major perspectives – developments, trends, and problems – in the economics of art and culture. The course will present the cultural economic perspective as developed by David Throsby, Bruno Frey, Arjo Klamer and other economic sociologists and contrast this with the standard economic approach to the arts and culture. The central question is how artists, consumers and cultural organizations realize the social and cultural values of art and culture. Another central theme is how cultural goods are priced and valued in the economy, within society, and within the art world. During the lectures these issues will be discussed from a theoretical perspective, while the workgroups will focus on the application of these theories to concrete economic phenomena or from the world of arts and culture that are familiar to students from their everyday life.</body>

<body>The goal of this course is to familiarize students with what has come to be called the cultural economic perspective. After this course students should be able to identify the differences between this perspective and the standard economic perspective, and they are expected to be able to analyze various phenomena using the cultural economic perspective.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81803,2018,The High Enlightenment I,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['prof.dr. L van Bunge'],,Inhoud

By 1750s the French Enlightenment in particular takes off its gloves. Diderot and D’Holbach start propagating a ‘Spinozist’ materialism, which raises the issue of the origins of the Radical Enlightenment. Simultaneously Rousseau singlehandedly revolutionizes French political thought. Meanwhile, the German Enlightenment (Thomasius, Wolff, Lessing) gets under way and the eighteenth-century culture of sensibility spreads throughout Europe. Following the French Revolution, Burke and De Maistre launch their Counter-Enlightenment, the echoes of which can still be traced in twentieth-century critical accounts of the Enlightenment such as Adorno and Horkheimer’s Dialectics of Enlightenment.
To fulltime students of Philosophy the seminars are compulsory.

Having completed this course, students will be familiar with some of the main ideas put forward by D’Holbach and the so-celled ‘radical Enlightenment’. They will understand the main characteristics of Rousseau’s thought. They will be able to distinguish some of the key differences between the French and the German Enlightenment. They will know some of the most important critical assessments of the Enlightenment, put forward during the late eighteenth and the twentieth centuries.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81802,2018,The High Enlightenment II: Kant,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. P Schuurman', 'prof.dr. HA Krop']",,"Inhoud

<body>David Hume’s criticism of the notion of causality prompted Immanuel Kant to develop a new philosophy in which causality is no longer a property of the world outside us, but rather a concept in our minds that assists us in making sense of the world. This is his famous ‘Copernican Revolution’
column2: rather than objects in the world shaping the cognitive operations of subjects (epistemological realism), these subjective operations determine our perceptions of objects and our judgements about objects (epistemological idealism). This is only part of Kant’s enormous contribution to philosophy. In his ethics he defended morality in the form of a law that demands to be obeyed for its own sake, the commands of which are not issued by some alien authority but the voice of reason that the moral subject can recognize as his own. Finally, although Kant was a great Enlightened demolisher of the truth of metaphysics, he nevertheless maintained that certain notions can still have a useful regulative function
column3: one example is the notion of teleology. This notion plays a major role in his philosophy of history, his political philosophy and his radical plea for world peace, Perpetual Peace (1795)
column4: paradoxically enough, this teleological perspective also implies a surprisingly positive evaluation of the function of war.

column1: The seminars are obligatory for fulltime students of Philosophy. Fulltime students can skip one session without any apology to the teacher. (Reserve this option for calamities.) For each additional session, please do not feel obliged to apologise either, but hand in an additional mini-essay. The mini-essay should start with a thesis or question that is clearly related to the prescribed literature, followed by a short argumentation that is used to defend the thesis or answer the question. The mini-essay will be marked. The mark for the mini-essay replaces the result for the highest marked question of the eight questions of the examination. For the document of the mini-essay please use the extensions .doc .docx or .rtf. For the name of your mini-essay please use the following format: <

column10: give the title, followed by the essay itself
column11: conclude with the number of words of the essay. Use a line spacing of one with a Palatino Linotype 12 point letter, and try to write your mini-essay on one single A4.

A basic understanding of Kant’s metaphysics, epistemology, ethics, philosophy of war and peace, and his philosophy of history.</body>

RBC Huijsmans', 'E Papyrakis', 'prof.dr. M Arsel', 'prof.dr. P Knorringa', 'prof.dr. RA Icaza Garza', 'prof.dr. W Harcourt', 'prof.mr.dr. CJM Arts', 'W Harcourt']",,"Inhoud

The course is a critical introduction to theories and strategies of international development – looking at the making, unmaking and remaking of development from cultural, historical, and political economic perspectives. It aims building a dialogue between the students’ own experiences and knowledges of development with the different approaches of the course literature from development studies and beyond. The three modules focus on: narratives of economic development
column4: post development and alternatives to development. Emphasis will be on the analyses of development as a historical process, an aspiration, a discourse of power and set of practices and in engaging students in critical approaches to development as a study and as a practice. The course fosters an open learning environment using participatory interactive methodology in order to encourage co-learning knowledge generation. The course features interactive lectures, a group produced video essay and student-led workshops.

column1: Cornwall, A. and D. Eade, eds. (2010) Deconstructing Development Discourse: Buzzwords and Fuzzwords. Warwickshire: Practical Action Publishing.
Escobar, A. (1995) Encountering Development. Princeton: Princeton University Press.

column3: The Development Dictionary: a guide to knowledge as power.

column1: Sen, A. (1999) Development as Freedom. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

AV: “The Danger of the Single Story” http://www.ted.com/talks/chimamanda_adichie_the_danger_of_a_single_story?language=en
This course can only be taken as part of the LDE programme track ‘Migration and Development’
During the course the students will acquire a critical lens through which to analyze development by being able to:
a) Unpack development as a contested set of cultural, political, economic and historical processes and relations
b) Appraise how ‘development problems’ and ‘solutions’ are understood according to different conceptual approaches to development
c) Reflect critically on their own understanding of and encounters with development
d) Work collaboratively within a multidisciplinary and multicultural context to communicate ideas about the making of development visually, orally and in writing.
e) Engage in a critical dialogue on development studies with peers and staff

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82567,2018,The Moral Self,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. KME Bauer'],,"Inhoud

What shall we do? How shall we interact? What is (the) good? These fundamental normative questions are inseparable from the question: Who are we? Moral philosophy does not develop abstract theories of agency, morality and the Good – it deals with us.

In this course we will discuss about normative consequences of different conceptions of the subject of morality in different accounts of moral philosophy. We will distinguish between different concepts of the moral agent and different understandings of personal practical identity, integrate current findings of moral psychology, and confront traditional ideals of the moral self with future visions of trans- or posthuman subjects. Finally, we will ask in how far the self-understanding of human beings necessarily implies the idea of a moral self.

- You will be able to distinguish between different conceptions and ideals of the moral self and to understand how they have developed in the course of history and how they are used in current debates.

- You will be able to distinguish between different concepts of the moral agent as well as between different theories of personal practical identity, to discuss their normative implications and to articulate your own philosophical position with respect to the moral self.

- On this this footing you will be enabled to put ideas and ideals of the moral self into a broader context of human self-understanding and to critically discuss how they may have to be modified in view of future prospects and challenges.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81851,2018,The Politics of Skepticism,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,"['dr. TKAM de Mey', 'prof.dr. L van Bunge']",,"Inhoud

<div>The first half of the course introduces by means of online lectures the different kinds of skepticism and the main ideas of both the skeptics and their critics. In the subsequent seminars, the students critically discuss draft papers in which the relations are explored and investigated systematically&nbsp
column2: between skepticism on the one hand, and, on the other hand, contemporary political ideas and debates, such as toleration, relativism, fundamentalism, the roles of prejudices and populism,

column1: The second part of the course has a historical focus. For a wide variety of reasons during the sixteenth century Pyrrhonism enjoyed a remarkable comeback. Some experts would have it that modern Theory of Knowledge actually emerged from the sustained attempt to overcome the challenge of Pyrrhonism. In this course we will also address the moral and political ramifications of the spectre of skepticism: it would seem that early modern theories of religious toleration crucially depended on some variety of skepticism, while natural law theories were invoked in order to argue in favour of objective moral truths, and to silence the Pyrrhonists once and for all.

(1) the student is able to pinpoint and to explain systematically the relations between metaphysical, epistemological and conceptual skepticism on the one hand, and political ideas and debates on the other hand
(2) the student is able to pinpoint and to explain historically the relations between skeptics and skeptical traditions on the one hand, and political ideas and debates on the other hand
(3) the student is able to define and address, either systematically or historically, a problem of his or her own choice, relating to both skepticism and politics

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81805,2018,The Quest for Man I,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['prof.dr. J de Mul'],,"Inhoud
<body>The first part of the course offers a systematic overview of the main subjects &nbsp
column2: and concepts of Philosophical Anthropology (such as the place of man in the Cosmos, the relationship between body and mind, consciousness, action, freedom of will, (inter)subjectivity, reflexivity and language), and its relationship to other philosophical disciplines, such as ethics and social philosophy, and the empirical sciences and humanities, which deal with human beings, such as biological anthropology, neuroscience, psychology, sociology, history, and cultural anthropology.

column1: Next, we will distinguish the mechanistic, organismic, and hermeneutic conception of man and, inspired by Kant’s and Dilthey’s transcendental philosophy, we will analyze the third-person, second-person, and first person ontological perspectives connected to these conceptions. Against the background of the ‘Historization of the World View’, both in its naturalistic (Darwin) and hermeneutic (Dilthey) form, we will discuss Plessner’s philosophical anthropology as a still topical attempt to connect the two. Finally, against this background, will reflect on the possible futures of the human life form in the light of the so-called converging technologies (such as information technology, neuroscience, and biotechnology).</body>

At the end of this course the student understands and can use the key concepts of philosophical anthropology, is able to distinguish the differences between mechanistic, organismic, and hermeneutic approaches in the study of human nature, and has acquired a basic knowledge of the history and the possible futures of the human life from an evolutionary (Darwin), historical (Dilthey), and philosophical-anthropological (Plessner) perspective.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81804,2018,The Quest for Man II,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. AW Prins'],,Inhoud
<div>In this second part of ‘the Quest for Man’ we will focus on Phenomenological &amp
column2: Hermeneutical approaches. Our point of departure will be the fortuitousness of western philosophy and the unsolved, but ever tentalising question, how we may comprehend the phenomenon of human existence while simultaniously being 'subject' and 'object' of this attempt toward comprehension ourselves.

column1: Key figures in this course will be: Kierkegaard (on truth and individual existence), Husserl (on transcendental subjectivity as the ‘wonder of all wonders’), Heidegger (on the 'event' of being human and the framing of existence in the era of Technology), Sartre (the ontology of absolute freedom and radical responsibility), Merleau-Ponty (on the phenomenology of bodily perception), Gadamer (on philosophical hermeneutics) and Levinas (on questioning the primacy of ontology in phenomenology and western philosophy as a whole).
1. Understanding the historical predicaments of the ‘first-person perspective’ in Western Philosophy
2. Acquaintance with the main currents in the Phenomenological Movement and the ‘turn’ from Phenomenology to Hermeneutics
3. The ability to assess the importance, relevance and limitations of the philosophical positions presented and discussed during the course, and taking well-argued positions
4. Acknowledging the importance of, and being able to practice ‘stirring thinking’</body>

The Research Workshop extends across terms 2 to 4 , preparing the students for writing their master’s thesis and guiding the writing process. This workshop comprises all phases, from writing the thesis

to presenting the final result. Students choose their own research subjects within the broad overall theme of the Research Workshop. A thesis market is organized before the start of term 2, whereafter students select one of the Research Workshops and research themes on offer. Every Research Workshop is structured in the same way:

column2: discussion of literature as an introduction to the theme
one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
critical discussion of the research proposals
discussion of and information on possible research methods
discussion of case studies and other work in progress
one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
discussion of case studies and other work in progress
one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
presentation of the thesis research at master conference in June 2018

column1: The final grade will be determined at the end of term 4 .
Theme: The Rise and Fall of the American Empire

Both in military and economic terms the United States of America grew into the most powerful empire of the world during the twentieth century. Just like the British Empire a century ago, the United States endeavoured to bring free markets, the rule of law, and democracy to the rest of the world. However, at the beginning of the twentieth first century, America’s military, political and economic power is seriously challenged. Rising economies like China and India threaten its economic position. Simultaneously, the American empire shows signs of military overstretch
column2: its military power is challenged by Russia, China, North Korea, Iran and Muslim fundamentalists. Most recently, American protectionism poses a real treat to global trade and prosperous economic development.. This research workshop will explore the rise and possible fall of the American colossus in a historical context.

column1: Further information at the Thesis Market in October
• Students can adequately and efficiently structure and conduct historical research
• Students can critically assess and discuss the research design, data collection and methodology of their master’s thesis
• Students can analyse, report and present their research findings
• Students can present their ideas and work- in-progress
• Students can constructively comment on the research of their peers

<body>The overall aim of this course is to integrate knowledge of legal philosophy and socio-legal studies by discussing the application of these fields to the rule of law. More particularly, the course aims are that students are able to&nbsp
• Explain the history and development of (the concept of) the rule of law
• Distinguish formal from substantial concepts of the rule of law, and their theoretical, political and empirical implications
• Analyse and relate theoretical and empirical problems of the rule of law in a situation of multilevel legal orders and global legal pluralism
• Analyse and debate how fulfilment of the ideals of the rule of law is challenged by fundamental value differences and private power holders
• Apply their knowledge and insights creatively to contemporary social and legal problems
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80219,2018,The Rules of the Game: Institutional Strategies,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['AJJ Maas'],,"Inhoud

The institutional context in which firms operate consists of the so called “rules of the game”. It encompasses the socially (humanly) constructed guidelines that describe how firms should behave, ranging from legally binding rules and laws to the expectations of customers, shareholders, employees or other stakeholders regarding business practices and organizational goals.

By not obliging these rules a firm can face serious consequences, such as fines, boycotts, or reduced access to vital knowledge or resources. However, the prescribed behavior of these rules are often not in line with the goals of the firm. Moreover, firms frequently operate in a complex environment, where they have to contend with different expectations from different stakeholder groups, which are often not achievable simultaneously. For example, employees might prefer organizations to implement strategies that ensure their job security, while shareholders demand higher profits, activists want environmentally friendly practices, and governments can force organizations to implement strict safety regulations. For multinational corporations this complexity is even further amplified, as these firms face multiple sets of institutional settings simultaneously.

As firms are rarely able to satisfy all the “rules” that they are subjected to, they need to develop appropriate strategic responses to manage their institutional environment. Sometimes firms are successful in developing such as response (for example when Apple prevented the FBI from gaining access to private information of their users by questioning the legitimacy of the rule). Other times firms are unsuccessful in their institutional strategy, such as when Volkswagen attempted, and failed to hide their non-compliance with regard to emission laws resulting in huge fines and boycotts.

This course will teach you how to create the appropriate strategic responses for organizations when it comes to dealing with their institutional environment. It will do so by helping you identify the different types of institutional rules that organizations face, how these rules might conflict with each other, the selection of strategic tools available to firms when it comes to dealing with these rules, and which responses are appropriate for a firm in which situation.

This course will employ a variety of teaching methods, mostly consisting of short lectures with interactive discussions, and many extended discussions of case examples. Students are expected to come prepared to each session, by having read the mandatory readings for the session and actively participating in the class during the discussions.
<div>To understand what institutions are and how they influence firm behavior and strategy
<div>To analyze the different types of institutions that firm need to deal with
<div>To identify institutional complexity, and understand how this affects organizations
<div>To create a toolkit of available strategic options that firms have when dealing with institutions
To develop the skills to create successful firm strategies to deal with any institutional environment.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80028,2018,The Social Bases of Politics,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['HB Broekema, MSc', 'prof.dr. W de Koster']",,"Inhoud

column2: Society specialisation familiarises students with the sociological study of politics, focusing on social patterns in public attitudes and political behaviour. How can we understand social differences in support for various value orientations, ideologies, and political parties? And how can we explain social inequalities in political trust and political involvement, both in the formal political domain and in non-institutional politics? There has been a marked decline in Western societies from the 1960s onwards in encompassing political ideologies and the political salience of classic group identities such as classes and religions – a process often referred to as individualisation. This does, however, not imply that value conflicts, voting behaviour, and participation in social movements are no longer socially shaped. On the contrary: old social fault lines have given way to new ones. Systematically combining theories from both political sociology and political science with findings from empirical research, this course addresses the contemporary political relevance of these social cleavages. What are their present-day implications? Which groups currently clash over which issues, why is this the case, and how is this related to support for political parties? How can we interpret social differences in anti-immigrant sentiments, political trust, voter turnout, and political protest? And how are these political attitudes and behaviours influenced by online and offline social networks?

column1: Note: basic knowledge of quantitative social-scientific methods is needed in order to understand a substantial part of the mandatory literature.

column2: After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

column1: <li>Discuss the political salience of old and new social divisions and cleavages
<li>Formulate and explain social-scientific theories on social differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours
<li>Apply social-scientific theories on social differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours to contemporary social phenomena
• Critically reflect on social-scientific theories on social differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82879,2018,The potential and challenges of Big Data in healthcare,"Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['dr. RLE Wehrens', 'J Kostenzer', 'MJ Stevens, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Big Data is currently high on the agenda in healthcare and with good reason: the potential of Big Data for improving healthcare is enormous. Traditionally defined through 3 ‘V’s (the large volume or amount of data, the variety in kinds of data being collected and analyzed, and the velocity or speed of data processing), many scholars, practitioners and policy makers have outlined the large potential benefits of Big Data. With the advent of new analytical tools and the huge advances in the amounts of (health) data routinely generated and collected by various agencies (e.g. electronic health records, epidemiologic information, quality registries, smart devices, health apps), Big Data can be used to predict epidemics, cure disease, improve quality of life and avoid preventable deaths. At the same time, Big Data is far from uncontroversial. Critics invoke imaginaries of the rise of mass-surveillance states that feature in classic and modern dystopias such as George Orwell’s 1984 and Dave Eggers’ The Circle. A major fear of many critics is that Big Data will lead to an erosion of privacy and might lead forms of ‘algorithmic discrimination’ reaffirming and strengthening existing inequalities. The recent attention for better data protection legislation (GDPR) and the media attention for the Facebook-Cambridge Analytica-data scandal show that such legislative and privacy concerns become increasingly important to address.

This course provides students with insights into the potential and the challenges of Big Data in healthcare. Students will gain a better understanding of both the practical aspects of Big Data (how does it work?), but also the relevant political and managerial discussions about how to apply Big Data in healthcare contexts. This course therefore uses a broad, socio-technical perspective on Big Data that also takes into consideration the social, legal, and ethical aspects of Big Data. This broader perspective on Big Data is not only relevant for better understanding the promises and limits of Big Data, but also brings students as future healthcare managers in a better position to make balanced decisions about what Big Data can and cannot do.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82880,2018,The potential and challenges of Big Data in healthcare,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. JWM Weggelaar - Jansen', 'dr. RLE Wehrens', 'J Kostenzer', 'MJ Stevens, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Big Data is currently high on the agenda in healthcare and with good reason: the potential of Big Data for improving healthcare is enormous. Traditionally defined through 3 ‘V’s (the large volume or amount of data, the variety in kinds of data being collected and analyzed, and the velocity or speed of data processing), many scholars, practitioners and policy makers have outlined the large potential benefits of Big Data. With the advent of new analytical tools and the huge advances in the amounts of (health) data routinely generated and collected by various agencies (e.g. electronic health records, epidemiologic information, quality registries, smart devices, health apps), Big Data can be used to predict epidemics, cure disease, improve quality of life and avoid preventable deaths. At the same time, Big Data is far from uncontroversial. Critics invoke imaginaries of the rise of mass-surveillance states that feature in classic and modern dystopias such as George Orwell’s 1984 and Dave Eggers’ The Circle. A major fear of many critics is that Big Data will lead to an erosion of privacy and might lead forms of ‘algorithmic discrimination’ reaffirming and strengthening existing inequalities. The recent attention for better data protection legislation (GDPR) and the media attention for the Facebook-Cambridge Analytica-data scandal show that such legislative and privacy concerns become increasingly important to address.

This course provides students with insights into the potential and the challenges of Big Data in healthcare. Students will gain a better understanding of both the practical aspects of Big Data (how does it work?), but also the relevant political and managerial discussions about how to apply Big Data in healthcare contexts. This course therefore uses a broad, socio-technical perspective on Big Data that also takes into consideration the social, legal, and ethical aspects of Big Data. This broader perspective on Big Data is not only relevant for better understanding the promises and limits of Big Data, but also brings students as future healthcare managers in a better position to make balanced decisions about what Big Data can and cannot do.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/79860,2018,The secrets of the skin,Nederlands,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,['dr. H.B. Thio', 'drs. P.K. Dikrama']",,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81834,2018,Theatre and Plasticity of the Human I,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. S van Tuinen'],,"Inhoud

We ask how the sciences of man and of the social perceive what is human and how it is situated in the world. Man and world are not universal, static givens but particular, dynamics products of a multitude of forces and institutions that we usually classify as e.g. economic, social, political, cultural, psychological, historical, architectural, ecological. These perspectives are each tied up with (modern) sciences that propose and legitimate conceptions of both the human and the world. Philosophical anthropology both competes with these perspectives, and aims to bring them together, in a continuing attempt to understand how the human relates to the world and how this is expressed in human self-understanding.

In this course, we will investigate the relation between man and world in terms of the ‘plasticity of the human’. Today a key concept at the intersection between medicine, design and politics, plasticity is the center-piece of the neurosciences, where it is used to describe the way in which the brain molds itself, developing its own history and historicity beyond genetic predetermination. But it also has a long philosophical history, from its invention by Goethe to Hegel, Nietzsche and Freud, in which it constitutes the transformative continuity between nature and history and between the neuronal and the mental. Plasticity thus raises a challenge for traditional humanistic ideas about the good life: according to what criteria and ends do we actively and passively produce ourselves, and thus also design and compose our social life, our brains, and our planet? Or as Friedrich Nietzsche puts it: How do we become who we are? Starting from a recuperation of the age-old philosophical problem of habit, an exploration of this question will take us to question the ends of man, the nature of history, the malleability of capitalist society, transformations of power and work, and ultimately questions of what to do with the brain and the earth.
<body>- Grasping, and be able to productively work with, differences and similarities in the understanding of the human in philosophy, and in the social and cultural sciences
- Understanding the plastic dimension of the human
- The ability to apply philosophical concepts to one’s own discipline and to use them to navigate ‘sister disciplines’.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81833,2018,Theatre and Plasticity of the Human II,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. GH van Oenen', 'Dr. S. van Tuinen']",,"Inhoud

We ask how the sciences of man and of the social perceive what is human and how it is situated in the world. Man and world are not universal, static givens but particular, dynamics products of a multitude of forces and institutions that we usually classify as e.g. economic, social, political, cultural, psychological, historical, architectural, ecological. These perspectives are each tied up with (modern) sciences that propose and legitimate conceptions of both the human and the world. Philosophical anthropology both competes with these perspectives, and aims to bring them together, in a continuing attempt to understand how the human relates to the world and how this is expressed in human self-understanding.

In this course, we will investigate this relation as a ‘theatre of the human’: the human is something performed, performing, and performative, acting within, and out of, the conditions and affordances of the world as he (mis)understands, appropriates, incorporates, and abnegates them. The sciences of man and of the social, to be sure, do not just study, describe, and explain this theatre
column2: they are performative as well, in their representation of the theatrical structure and their rendering of the human and the world. The sciences, in other words, are themselves part of the theatre of the human.

column1: - grasping, and be able to productively work with, differences and similarities in the understanding of the human in philosophy, and in the social and cultural sciences
- understanding the plastic dimension of the human</body>

G1 Aan de hand van voorbeelden kun je onderstaande onderwerpen bespreken die een rol spelen bij de beroepsuitoefening van een arts:
professioneel gedrag en handelen in relatie tot het eigen gedrag en handelen
G2 Je kunt het belang aangeven van het gebruik van de medische terminologie, kent de in thema Ba.1.A gebruikte medische termen en kunt ze gebruiken.
G3 Je kent de anatomie en fysiologie van het menselijk lichaam, zoals uitgewerkt bij de specifieke leerdoelen.
G4 Je kent het driedimensionale bouwplan van het menselijk lichaam als concept, onderliggend aan de lokalisatie van klachten en symptomen.
G5 Je kunt uitgangspunten benoemen voor een professionele arts-patiënt relatie.
G6 Je kunt medische en wetenschappelijke informatie vinden, beoordelen en presenteren.
G7 Je kent de basisprincipes die ten grondslag liggen aan het denken en handelen als arts-academicus.
G8 Je kunt het belang van een persoonlijk netwerk beargumenteren.
G9 Je hebt inzicht in het eigen studiegedrag.</body>
Thema De Gezonde Mens is het thema waarin in elf weken de basis gelegd wordt voor begrip van en inzicht in het normale functioneren van de gezonde mens.

Verder is het vanzelfsprekend de eerste kennismaking met de studie geneeskunde en wordt er ook alvast een 'blik geworpen' op de latere uitoefening van het beroep waartoe deze studie opleidt: het beroep van arts.

De oriëntatie op de studie zal vooral in de eerste weken plaats vinden. Zaken als: omgaan met en het zoeken van informatie, het gebruik van Blackboard en SIN-Online, maar ook het verkrijgen van inzicht in je eigen leerproces en de manier waarop je dit leerproces kunt sturen komen aan de orde. Gedurende de rest van thema Ba.1.A zullen in het mentoraat en tutoraat een scala aan onderwerpen behandeld worden, die een rol spelen in de opleiding tot arts.

Stoornissen in het milieu interieur is het eerste grote thema en kent dezelfde opbouw als de andere grote themata. In een korte inleiding (deel 1) wordt duidelijk gemaakt wat milieu interieur eigenlijk is en wat de bijdrage is van hart, bloedvaten, longen en nieren aan het handhaven van de homeostase van het milieu interieur.

Stoornissen kunnen optreden als gevolg van tal van factoren, zoals afwijkende samenstelling of intake van voeding, (bijvoorbeeld: psychische factoren, dysfagie, braken, passage en motiliteitsstoringen), abnormale voedselverwerking (bijvoorbeeld: aangeboren en verworven stofwisselingsziekten) en abnormale hormonale en/of neuronale regulatie. Klachten die hierbij optreden, zoals vermagering, vetzucht, braken, diarree, obstipatie, misselijkheid, dorst en geelzien, vormen het uitgangspunt bij de bestudering van deze vraagstukken.

Opgedane kennis over de deelconcepten van verstoorde voeding, metabolisme en hormonale regulatie pas je toe op de ziektebeelden: diabetes type 1 en 2, obesitas, osteoporose, icterus, hypo- en hyperthyreo&iuml
column2: die, ulcus ventriculi en duodeni, anemie, en levercirrose.

column1: Voor meer informatie: zie het themaboek voor Ba1C of de Geneeskundewebsite.

Vanuit het concept homeostase bestudeer je eerst de normale en dan de decompenserende mechanismen die samenhangen met voeding, metabolisme en hormonale regulatie. Centrale vraagstellingen hierbij zijn:

column10: Waarom is voeding belangrijk?
Hoe neemt het lichaam voeding tot zich en hoe wordt deze opname gereguleerd?
Wat zijn de belangrijkste voedingsbronnen en wat essenti&euml
Hoe worden voedingsbestanddelen opgeslagen en wanneer worden ze gemobiliseerd?
Wat zijn de regulerende processen tijdens groei en ontwikkeling en veroudering?
Wat is het effect van storingen in deze normale processen op het functioneren van het lichaam?
Wat zijn de effecten van afname van de voedselinname?
Welke processen functioneren geleidelijk aan minder goed bij het ouder worden en wat zijn hiervan de consequenties?

Het thema ‘Oncologie’ richt zich op alle medisch relevante aspecten, die betrekking hebben op kanker. Kanker is, na hart- en vaatziekten, de tweede doodsoorzaak in de Westerse wereld en zal volgens de huidige trends over enige tijd doodsoorzaak nummer één zijn.

Week 1 introduceert het thema en geeft een overzicht van de globale opbouw. Tevens maak je kennis met verschillende facetten van het probleem kanker, aan de hand van een aantal patiënten. Het verschaft de basis voor de moleculaire, cellulaire en weefsel aspecten, die aan de orde komen in de erop volgende weken.&nbsp
column2: In de weken 2 t/m 7 krijg je inzicht in de kenmerken van kanker
column3: hoe het ontstaat, de relatie tussen het ziektebeeld en de klachten, de&nbsp
column4: diagnose, prognose, therapie, beloop en kanker op populatieniveau.

column1: In de weken 8 t/m 12 pas je de in deel 1 opgedane kennis, inzichten en vaardigheden toe op concrete klinische situaties, waarin per week een orgaan(systeem) centraal staat.
In de weken 13 en 14 ligt de nadruk op methoden van wetenschap en is er een voorbereiding op het keuzeonderwijs.</body>

Het thema ‘Infectie- en immuunziekten’ bestaat uit drie delen. Hieronder volgt een korte beschrijving per deel.

Periode 1 begint met een overzicht van de opzet en inhoud van het thema ‘Infectie- en immuunziekten’. Aan de hand van een aantal demonstraties van met HIV geïnfecteerde patiënten en hun problemen, komen de basisbegrippen binnen de immunologie en infectieziekten/microbiologie aan bod. Aangezien HIV/AIDS nog steeds een beladen onderwerp is, is ook een college genaamd ‘Ethiek rondom HIV’ opgenomen.

Na deze inleidende week worden themagewijs de belangrijkste concepten binnen de immunologie en infectieziekten / microbiologie besproken. Dit gaat door in periode 2 van het thema. Hiermee wordt de basis gelegd voor de integratie van kennis, inzicht en vaardigheden die nodig zijn voor het kunnen omgaan met patiënten met een (vermoede) infectie en / of immuunziekte. Elke week heeft een eigen onderwerp en daarmee ook een geheel eigen karakter. Aan het eind van deze periode (week 5) wordt het eerste tentamen gehouden.

In deze periode worden bepaalde basisconcepten verder uitgewerkt, en al enige aandacht besteed aan klinische symptomalogie van (groepen van) infectie- en immuunziekten. Ook in deze periode gebeurt dit weer aan de hand van een onderwerp dat een hele week centraal staat. In een aantal weken is ook een college ingeroosterd over nieuwe actuele ontwikkelingen. Zo staat in week Ba.2.B.10 een college gepland over nieuwe ontwikkelingen in de reumatologie. In week 7 wordt in een e-ZO gestart met het uitwerken van casuïstiek.

In dit deel (6 weken) worden de medisch en/of didactisch belangrijkste infectie- en immuunziekten in detail behandeld. Hierbij leggen we vooral de nadruk op een geïntegreerde benadering van de patiënt en zijn/haar klachten. Daarnaast wordt de nodige aandacht besteed aan nieuwe ontwikkelingen ten aanzien van pathofysiologische inzichten, diagnostiek en therapie. Deels gebeurt dit orgaanspecifiek. Zo komen in de eerste 3 weken van deel 3 achtereenvolgens het centraal zenuwstelsel, de luchtwegen en de huid aan bod. In de vierde week worden met name ziektes uit de tropen besproken. De laatste 3 weken van dit deel is gekozen voor ziektebeelden die een meervoudige problematiek hebben. Aan de hand van gegevens uit anamnese, en lichamelijk en aanvullend onderzoek, bepaal je het hoofdprobleem, stel je een differentiaaldiagnose op en besluit je tot een nader diagnostisch en/of therapeutisch plan. Je werkt hierbij zowel zelfstandig als in groepsverband. Daarnaast leer je over de nieuwe ontwikkelingen binnen de immunologie en infectieziekten/microbiologie door eigen presentaties tijdens diverse symposia.
Het thema wordt afgesloten door het derde tentamen.</body>

Het thema ‘Infectie- en immuunziekten’ bestrijkt een breed scala van aandoeningen, van orgaanspecifieke tot systemische, van acute tot chronische, en van zeldzaam tot zeer frequent voorkomende ziektebeelden. Koorts is hierbij een vaak op de voorgrond staand verschijnsel.
Nog niet zolang geleden werd het voor mogelijk gehouden infectieziekten uit te bannen, maar niets bleek minder waar: nieuwe infectieziekten (SARS, Vogelgriep, Meningococcen, Mond- &amp
column2: Klauwzeer, HIV/AIDS), oude infectieziekten in nieuwe gedaantes (TBC) en resistentieontwikkeling voor antimicrobiële middelen (MRSA, VRE), hebben ervoor gezorgd dat infectieziekten weer voorpaginanieuws zijn. Ook de incidentie van immuunziekten is de afgelopen decennia gestegen, en ook hier geldt dat steeds meer ziektebeelden een immunologische oorzaak blijken te hebben. In het thema wordt ook uitgebreid stilgestaan bij de interactie tussen afweer en infectie: verminderde afweer (immuundeficiënties) en verhoogde gevoeligheid voor infecties
column4: infecties die leiden tot verminderde afweer (bijvoorbeeld HIV en CMV)
column5: en behandeling van immuunziekten die leiden tot infectieproblemen.

column1: Binnen het thema is getracht om alle onderwijsvormen zo op elkaar af te stemmen dat overlap zoveel als mogelijk is vermeden. Dit houdt in dat de tentamenstof ook evenredig over de verschillende onderwijsvormen is verdeeld.</body>

Het thema bestaat uit 5 weken en dus uit 5 onderwerpen/regio’s, elk onderwerp wordt vanuit een bepaalde lichaamsregio bekeken:

column10: &nbsp
&nbsp
column33: Gezwollen gewrichten / Onderarm, pols en hand

column10: &nbsp
column33: Degeneratieve gewrichtsaandoeningen / Bekken, heup en bovenbeen &nbsp

column10: &nbsp
column33: De harde val / Knie, onderbeen, enkel, voet

column10: &nbsp

column1: In deze 5 weken is sprake van zogenaamd integratie vaardigheidsonderwijs (IVO), waarin bouw en functie, beeldvormende technieken, de (operatieve) behandeling en het onderzoek van de patiënt integraal worden behandeld.

Verder komen binnen dit thema van alle aandoeningen de Histologie, Biochemie, Microscopische anatomie en de Pathologie geïntegreerd aan de orde. Voor de gelegenheid, en alleen in dit thema, is een onderwijsgroep van samenwerkende afdelingen gevormd: groep ‘HBMP’.
Elke nieuwe week begint op donderdag met colleges en patiëntdemonstraties waarmee je een referentiekader kunt opbouwen.&nbsp

column4: De student kan de normale en de verstoorde anatomische en fysiologische ontwikkeling van het houdings- en bewegingssysteem beschrijven
De student kan de anatomie, fysiologie en de pathofysiologie van skelet en spieren beschrijven in de hiertoe geëigende terminologia anatomica
De student kan bij problemen en ziekten in verschillende regio’s&nbsp
column5: van het houdings- en bewegingssysteem de daarbij horende etiologie, pathogenese en de pathofysiologie beschrijven, een juiste diagnose stellen, een passende therapie selecteren en een uitspraak doen over prognose en verloop.

column4: De student kan de functies aangeven die de verschillende behandelmethoden&nbsp
column5: vervullen: screening, diagnostiek en preventie van aangeboren afwijkingen en ziekten.

column4: De student kan patiëntklachten relateren aan de pathofysiologie van het probleem of de ziekte en zich daarbij inleven in de patiënt.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80047,2018,Theoretische Sociologie,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. W Schinkel'],,"Inhoud
<body>In dit vak wordt stilgestaan bij de kernproblemen van de sociologische theorie. We doen dat door voort te bouwen op het B1-vak&nbsp
column2: Geschiedenis van de Sociologie. Aan bod komen onder meer de perspectieven van Erving Goffman, Jürgen Habermas, Pierre Bourdieu, Michel Foucault, Niklas Luhmann, Bruno Latour, Judith Butler en Cedric Robinson. Centraal staan de theoretische problemen van de verhouding tussen individu en sociaal collectief, en tussen samenleving en natuur. We zullen zien hoe met die problemen op heel fundamenteel verschillende manieren is omgegaan.

column1: <li>Inzicht in het theoretische probleem van de verhouding tussen individu en sociaal collectief
• Vaardigheid opdoen met het schrijven van een boekbespreking (zoals in een tijdschrift).

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81608,2018,Theoretische criminologie,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['drs. E Jaspers', 'prof.dr. R van Swaaningen', 'SD Kruit, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Theoretische criminologie beoogt inzicht te bieden in 1) de wetenschapstheoretische uitgangspunten van de criminologie, 2) de verschillende verklaringen van criminaliteit en van sociale reacties, en 3) de mogelijkheden om verschillende theorie&euml
column2: n toe te passen op drie probleemgebieden (geweld, fraude &amp
column3: drugs) en te integreren. Door zowel recente als vroegere inzichten aan bod te laten komen wordt een beeld gegeven van de ontwikkeling van de criminologie als wetenschap, en hoe deze door maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen wordt be&iuml

column1: verschillen en overeenkomsten aangeven tussen de verschillende theoretische stromingen in termen van onderzoeksvragen, verklaringen, assumpties en niveaus van verklaring
de inhoud van de belangrijkste criminologische verklaringen kennen en toepassen op concrete (kennis)problemen en delicten
op basis van informatie over onderzoeksbevindingen conclusies trekken over de empirische houdbaarheid van theorie&euml
aangeven op welke manier maatschappelijke condities het bijeenbrengen en toepassen van wetenschappelijke kennis over criminaliteit en crimineel gedrag kunnen be&iuml

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81397,2018,Theorie en geschiedenis van het hedendaagse strafrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. CL van der Vis', 'mr.drs. MW Kouwenberg', 'prof.mr. J uit Beijerse']",,"Inhoud

De huidige regeling van het straf- en strafprocesrecht is de resultante van een geschiedenis van ideeën, systeemtheoretische opvattingen en wettelijke regelingen, in relatie met meer feitelijke (maatschappelijke) ontwikkelingen. In dit vak worden voor diverse belangrijke kenmerken en leerstukken van het geldende straf- en strafprocesrecht de grondslagen nagegaan. Hiermee vormt het vak de theoretische en historische achtergrond voor drie grote, en grotendeels positiefrechtelijk georiënteerde, verplichte vakken in de mastervariant: Onderzoekspracticum verdiepend formeel strafrecht, Verdiepend materieel strafrecht en Sanctierecht. De positiefrechtelijke stand van zaken is immers niet enkel een gegeven, maar als vanzelfsprekend ook een – mogelijk vanuit actueel perspectief betwistbare – uitkomst van historische discussies of keuzes. Deze benadering levert handvatten voor kritische analyse op, die van essentieel belang zijn voor een niet alleen op de praktijk maar ook op wetenschap gerichte opleiding in het strafrecht.

Het vak is opgebouwd aan de hand van capita selecta uit de drie genoemde deelgebieden. De verschillende onderwerpen worden daarbij, waar aangewezen tevens zoveel mogelijk in chronologische volgorde behandeld. Zo worden er vragen behandeld als: Wat is het rechtskarakter van het straf(proces)recht? Waarom heeft ons strafproces zich sinds het Romeinse forum als inquisitoir ontwikkeld? Waarom is niet elk ongewenst gedrag strafbaar en welk ongewenst gedrag eigenlijk wel? Wat leren ons discussies uit de totstandkomingsgeschiedenis van de Wetboeken van Strafrecht en Strafvordering voor een goed begrip van actuele thema’s als de plaats van de raadsman bij het politieverhoor? Waarom wordt op misdaad eigenlijk met straf gereageerd en waarom met het specifieke sanctie-arsenaal dat wij hebben?

Het vak bouwt mede voort op bacheloronderwijs in de rechtstheorie en -geschiedenis en behandelt met name de specifiek strafrechtstheoretische ontwikkeling, waarbij veel aandacht zal worden besteed aan de stromingen die het huidige strafrecht en strafrechtelijk debat (nog steeds) kleuren. Bij verschillende onderdelen zal ook een rechtsvergelijkend perspectief (nationaal en internationaal) worden geboden, zodat duidelijk wordt waarin en waarom andere rechtsstelsels thans verschillen, als gevolg van een andere theoretische- en historische ontwikkeling.</body>
<li>De grondslagen en kenmerken van het geldende strafprocesrecht, materiële strafrecht en sanctierecht verklaren vanuit hun theoretische en historische ontwikkeling
<li>Belangrijke verschillen in grondslagen en ontwikkeling met andere rechtsstelsels, zowel nationaal als internationaal, doorgronden
<li>Samenwerken in het voorbereiden en verzorgen van een presentatie ten aanzien van de theoretische en historische grondslagen van een strafrechtelijk of maatschappelijk vraagstuk
• Een kritische visie vormen op de maatschappelijke rol van het strafrecht aan de hand van diens theoretische en historische ontwikkeling en bijbehorende ethische perspectieven.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80788,2018,Theories on Change, on Behaviour and on Differences",Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. AJJA Maas', 'dr. MJ Flory']",,"Inhoud

The main objective of this second course is to deepen insights into actual change situations – taking into account not only the organization itself, but also the social, political and cultural context in which changes occur. Change can here relate to strategic changes, which tend to be planned), but also to unplanned changes, which need to be managed.

We will do this by reading (about) and using post-modern and social constructionist change theory, methods and concepts. Building on and extending previously acquired knowledge on organisational development and change, the course helps students: 1) to acquire the relevant conceptual and methodological foundation and 2) to develop the social, political and personal sensitivity crucial for a role as change agent (manager or consultant).

How do we do that? In a first trajectory a varied range of perspectives is offered that will highlight paradigmatic patterns of thought involved in the way change is conceptualized in organisations and society at large. This includes considerations of multi-level processes and the complexity of social behaviours in change. The second trajectory treats the theories, concepts, and methods that offer students a frame of reference for the diagnosis and handling of differences in change situations. This includes the consideration of multiple perspectives, agendas, expectations and politics, as well as the (explicit or implicit) impact of disparate social and organizational contexts. The third trajectory is used to engage students in situations where they may experience change and actually work with the concepts, methods and instruments offered throughout the course. Cases, documentaries, TV and film fragments invite students to search for their own relational practice, to experience and diagnose a specific change situation directly, and to analyse and understand the meaning and contexts of the particular situation. Related to a practical case chosen during the course, methods of perception, reflection, intake, diagnostics and intervention are practised and explained.

The course is given once per week, alternating between theoretical and methodological lectures. Theoretical lectures review relevant theories on change and analyses their relation with organizational change. In these theoretical lectures the connections with debates in change studies are made visible and tested for their applicability to organizational change.

In the methodological lectures we look into methodological questions relevant for a change agent: how do we develop a change attitude? How do we observe, listen, diagnose and analyse different change situations when we take the positions and theories reviewed in the first lectures take seriously? The main emphasis in these lectures is on creating practical knowledge and insights, as well as sensitivity to how the own stance of change agent affects their choices, foci and behaviours.

In this course, study and inquiry will be done in teams of five students. Each week the teams are asked to write a short analysis on the main characteristics, similarities, and differences of the treated theories. Teams also do field work in a real-life project, which teams will be asked to inquire and present. In a final paper, teams report on their overall diagnosis and findings from their project. Finally, students are asked to present their individual personal lessons in a self-assessment paper.
The Learning Objectives for this course are:
To look at and understand social behavioural processes in organisational change where plurality and synchronicity are actual items
To enable students to experience, analyze and understand change as systems of interlinked organizations and stakeholders in more or less profound, continuous transition
To support students to develop a theoretical basis to understand, analyze and prepare change in diverse organisational and social contexts
To provide students with a toolbox of methods to evaluate change processes and outcomes
To test out and practice the role of change agents in a real-life project
Be able to analyze the relevant social and political context of organizational changes
Be able to prepare, diagnose and guide change processes cognitively, as well as socially
Be able to relate perspectives of change to diagnosis methods of change, and combine different diagnosis methods in particular change situations
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81072,2018,Theory of the Avant-Garde,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. N van Poecke'],,"Inhoud

<body>Avant-garde is the French military term for “front-guard” and is generally used to describe the most adventurous manifestations of modern art. Art that forges ahead, that is innovative, breaks down barriers and challenges the status quo
column2: but at the same time, art that is difficult, sometimes incomprehensible and elitist. Through a combination of the humanities and sociological perspectives, we will trace the roots of the Western avant-garde, examine the challenges that avant-garde artists faced (and still face today) and discuss whether avant-garde art is still possible today and if so, in what kind of manifestations. As this course is a seminar, students are responsible for much of the course’s discussion. Students will contribute to the course by being responsible for examination of the assigned literature and presentation of case studies that serve as exemplars. In this way, the class is research intensive, relying on student interests to direct the exploration of the course's main themes. The course is entirely in English, requires class participation and presentation, individual and group work, and extensive and creative written work.</body>

column1: <body>The aim of the course is to create insight into the relationships between changes in the (visual) arts and popular culture, on the one hand, and changes in society, on the other, for approximately the last 200 years. Students will become familiar with the most influential theories of the avant-garde, the most influential critiques of avant-garde art, and the most ‘canonical’ examples of avant-garde art – from Duchamp’s urinal to Barnett Newman’s abstract paintings, and from Manet to David Foster Wallace,&nbsp
column2: relational aesthetics and theories of post-postmodernism. Students will be able to think, read, write and talk about avant-garde art in its socio-historical and philosophical context
column4: create self-formulated questions, and make an avant-garde art work themselves.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/78999,2018,Thesis Pedagogical Sciences,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['dr. AP Ringoot', 'dr. LAL de Meijer', 'dr. MHF Deutz', 'dr. WA van der Schuur', 'RJ Zijderveld, MSc', 'S Schouwenburg']",,"Inhoud

The master’s thesis is the final part of the master program. During this final phase, students apply their knowledge and skills in the field of pedagogical and educational research. By formulating relevant academic research questions and carrying out a subsequent research, students contribute to the collective knowledge base of professionals and academics in the field of pedagogy and education.

The master thesis is an academic written product, an academic aptitude test in which students reflect their academic level. The master thesis describes empirical research in form of an academic article and contributes to the knowledge of pedagogical or educational science.

current insights, key theories, empirical findings, and national and international developments, both within the chosen specialization and at the interface of the three specializations (i.e. ortho pedagogy, family pedagogy and educational sciences)

cultural (i.e. ethnic-cultural, ethical and/or legal), economic, social and/or political developments within the chosen specialization, and related issues, problems and findings (including empirical findings)

advanced methods and models used in the process of signaling and identifying complex, multi-problem pedagogical situations and providing appropriate guidance and support, both at the level of the individual and at the level of systems and institutions

intervention (or treatment) models of complex, multiple pedagogical problems, including their effectiveness and their application in a diverse context (i.e. diversity in ethnic-culture, social-economic status, legislation, language, gender)
advanced designs and methods for social sciences research.
assess and translate complex pedagogical problems into interventions, programs and/or policy, and&nbsp
carry out research within the chosen specialization and at the interface with other related sub disciplines of the pedagogical sciences

analyze complex questions, issues and developments in the field of upbringing and education and form a well-reasoned opinion by integrating existing knowledge and their own understanding with the ability to reflect on the limitations of their knowledge and on the influence of their own and other people’s culture-based norms and values

carry out their pedagogic and scientific work with an awareness of ethical and culture-related aspects, in respect of clients as well as test subjects, and to oversee the consequences of their own professional actions
work in a multidisciplinary group in a pedagogical context, and competently take on either a leading role or a team role

communicate complex themes, either orally or in writing, in a clear and comprehensible way, with the ability to differentiate between different target groups (e.g. children, parents, teachers, policymakers, scientists and other professionals) and accounting for diversity
keep up with subject-related developments and developments in society in order to contribute to change processes in pedagogic practice and to innovation in the field of pedagogy
column2: independently engage in a further specialist study program and continue working on their professional development.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82544,2018,Thesis Report,Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,['dr. MKA Kniou'],,Inhoud
Mundus MAPP includes a significant research training and independent research component, preparing students for further studies and/or jobs requiring research skills following graduation.

Work on the student’s research project starts with a short statement of thesis topic, submitted to ISS/CEU by 1 February of year one, stating a preference for a supervisor at the first year institution, who will act as primary supervisor in academic year one. In the following month, a second supervisor from York/IBEI will be allocated to the student, with this faculty member taking over primary supervisory responsibilities from the ISS/CEU supervisors when students progress from year 1 to 2. The two supervisors will collaborate and jointly advise the student during the two years of the program until the thesis is submitted.

The thesis report should be written after coursework finishes in the first academic year. The report serves as an advanced thesis proposal which already covers considerable ground for the thesis itself, to be written in year two. The report will be a paper of 6,000 words (including all references, footnotes, bibliography, appendices, and abstract), which includes a problem specification (research question/ rationale), initial literature review, methods and, where appropriate, hypotheses and case study selection
column2: as well as work plan detailing deadlines the student intends to observe for writing up the different parts of the thesis. The topic of the thesis report (and by extension the thesis) should be relevant to the student’s mobility track.

column1: The report is due by 1 September of year two, and is jointly graded by the two supervisors, each contributing half the final grade. Students receive detailed comments from the graders, and a single grade allocated in the ISS/CEU grading scheme.
The thesis report should achieve the following:
Lead us into the general, then the specific topic.
Indicate that there is a gap, an area or puzzle that is unanswered or unresolved.
State the research question (as a question, where methodologically appropriate).
Indicate briefly how this question will be answered (i.e. what methods you have chosen).
Point to the value of this research, either practical (how it will benefit policy) or academic (how it will advance our knowledge).
Provide a review of relevant literature and indicate how it well help you deal with the chosen topic.
Provide a work plan with deadlines and deliverables up to the end of the thesis writing period.
The thesis report will be marked in the ISS or CEU marking system, using the following assessment criteria:
Problem specification: Is the research question to be pursued in the thesis clear and suitable?
Does the thesis report provide a convincing rationale for pursuing the proposed research?
Presentation of concepts / theory: Does the report identify a suitable approach/theoretical framework/key concepts that will guide the thesis?

Literature review: does the report identify relevant body/bodies of literature? Does it show a good understanding of appropriate/relevant literature? Is the literature competently reviewed, and its relevance for the thesis well established?

Research design and methods: Is the report explicit about the research design of the planned thesis, including, where appropriate, hypotheses and case study selection? Does it provide a good discussion of planned data collection and analysis, of sources and methods that will be used? Are the chosen method/s well justified?
Referencing: Is the use of literature and sources competent? Is referencing in line with good scholarly standards?
General presentation: Is the report neatly presented and clearly structured? Is the language clear and correct? Is the report within (and not significantly shorter than) the expected 6,000 words?
Quality of work plan: Does the thesis report include a realistic work plan and time table towards completion of the thesis, of the major milestones and deliverables?
With the report the student demonstrates the capacity to:
choose an adequate method to research the problem

presented a convincing proposal for the final thesis including a statement regarding the objectives of the research, the research question, a short review of the relevant theoretical background and a statement on the methodology.

The final thesis takes the form of an individual research project. The topic can be chosen by the student, but it needs to be related to one or more of the GMD and PA courses in their track. The thesis must cover a governance issue in relation to migration and diversity, making use of the public administration literature to analyse a specific governance approach. For instance, a comparative analysis of how and why different countries or cities promote inter-ethnic contact, or an analysis of the impact of superdiversity on integration policymaking. Note that an internship is not part of our program.

The thesis trajectory consists of two parts: the thesis-proposal and the thesis-research. During this course [thesis-research] the students will execute the data-collection (where relevant) and analysis for the research question they formulated in the previous course and write their thesis in accordance to the academic standards. The process will be supervised in thesis circles where the proceedings are discussed with the supervisor and peers.

At the start of block 4, students will be matched with a supervisor, most likely one of the lecturers that taught the mandatory courses of this master program. This is coordinated by the GMD program directors and depends on the expertise and thesis-load of potential supervisors. After the manuscript has been approved by the supervisor, he or she will involve a second reader. When both approve the research project and all requirements of the GMD master have been satisfied, the thesis will be defended in front of the delegated examination board.
<body>In the process of conducting the research necessary to answer the research questions, and reporting on the study conducted, students learn:
<li>to independently conduct the empirical analysis on secondary or primary (self-collected) data, using relevant methods and techniques
<li>to independently draw and report academically sound conclusion(s) in relation to the research question and public administration and migration-literature
<li>to reflect on the conclusion in terms of limitations, theoretical and/or practical implications, and the need for further research
• to be able to clearly and adequately communicate the main findings of the study to both an expert and a lay audience.
• to clearly structure and fully reference a thesis.
